470 - 528 AH

text:
Introduction

Many men from Andalusia migrated to the East seeking knowledge, wealth, status, or desiring to perform the Hajj pilgrimage. Among those immigrants to Egypt was a man who combined literature with wisdom (philosophy), and medicine with astrology, music, mathematics, and proficiency in the science of mechanics. This man is Abu al-Salt Umayyah bin Abd al-Aziz bin Abi al-Salt, born in the city of Dénia, in Andalusia, in the year 470 AH.

Abu al-Salt arrived in Alexandria accompanied by his mother - according to Ibn Khallikan - in the year 487 AH. That is, during the days of the Fatimid Caliph Al-Mustansir Billah Abu Tamim Ma'ad bin Al-Zahir Billah Ali bin Al-Hakim bi-Amr Allah; and his vizier at that time, who was managing the affairs of his state, was Al-Afdal Shahanshah, son of the Commander of the Armies Badr al-Jamali the Armenian.

From this journey, Abu al-Salt hoped for an abundance of living and wealth, as he indicated at the beginning of his epistle. It seems that he remained obscure for a long time, waiting for opportunities, until he was able to contact one of those close to the Vizier Al-Afdal (1), during the days of the Caliph Al-Amir (2). That man was Taj al-Ma'ali Mukhtar (3). He served him with the crafts of medicine
foot_note:
1. Al-Afdal's vizierate for the Fatimid Al-Mustansir began in 487 after the death of his father Badr al-Jamali, then he was vizier for Al-Musta'li Billah Ahmad in 488, then for Al-Amir bi-Ahkam Allah in 496. He tyrannized over all these Caliphs until Al-Amir managed to overpower him and plotted his killing, so he was killed in 515. Al-Nujum al-Zahirah (5: 222).
2. He is Al-Amir bi-Ahkam Allah Mansur bin Al-Musta'li Billah Ahmad bin Al-Mustansir Billah. He was born in 490 and became Caliph when he was five years old, and it is said in 524. See Al-Nujum al-Zahirah (5: 17) and Al-Khitat al-Maqriziyyah regarding the mention of "Al-Aqmar Mosque."
3. Mu'jam al-Udaba (7: 54).

publisher: Mustafa al-Babi al-Halabi and Sons Library and Printing Company in Egypt
text:
and astrology, so he admired him, described him in the presence of Al-Afdal, and praised him. However, Al-Afdal's scribe envied him for that and feared the power of Taj al-Ma'ali. It happened that Taj al-Ma'ali's missteps followed one another, leading Al-Afdal to arrest and imprison him. Al-Afdal's scribe found the opportunity ripe to eliminate Abu al-Salt, so he fabricated things against him that drove Al-Afdal to throw him into the Ma'una Prison (1) in Cairo for a period of three years and a month (2), despite the panegyrics and poetry he had composed for him (3).

Ibn Abi Usaibia narrates in *Tabaqat al-Atibba* (Classes of Physicians) that Abu al-Salt's entry into Egypt was around the year 510 AH, and that he was imprisoned in Alexandria during the caliphate of Al-Amir bi-Ahkam Allah and the vizierate of Al-Afdal (4). If this narrative is correct, it would be evidence that Abu al-Salt arrived a second time after the death of his benefactor Abu al-Tahir Yahya bin Tamim bin Al-Muizz bin Badis (5), who died in the year 509, which is the year of his departure from Egypt.
foot_note:
1. Al-Maqrizi mentioned this prison when mentioning the Ma'muniyya House attributed to Al-Ma'mun Al-Bata'ihi. He said: "Next to the Ma'muniyya House was the Ma'una Prison." Then he said: "This place remained a prison during the Fatimid state and the Ayyubid state, until King Mansur Qalawun built a caravanserai (Qaysariyya) there and housed amber dealers in it in the year 680." He said: "This Ma'una Prison was where criminals were held... as for princes and notables, they were imprisoned in Khazanat al-Bunud." The Ma'muniyya House is what is known as the Suyufiyya Madrasa.
2. Al-Maqqari narrated in Nafh al-Tib (1: 530 Leiden) a strange account: that Abu al-Salt's age was 60 years; 20 in Seville, 20 in Ifriqiya (Tunisia) with its Zirid kings, and 20 in Egypt imprisoned in the Library.
3. See some of it in Ibn Abi Usaibia (2: 53, 56).
4. Ibn Abi Usaibia mentioned the reason for his imprisonment in Alexandria: Al-Afdal asked him to devise a trick (mechanism) to raise a ship sunk in the sea. Abu al-Salt strove, but when he neared success, his luck betrayed him, and the ship sank to the bottom of the sea, after costing the state heavy losses, so Al-Afdal imprisoned him for that.
5. Abu al-Tahir Yahya bin Tamim became king of the Maghreb in 501 and remained stable in his rule until he died in 509. See History of Tripoli by Ibn Ghalbun (pp. 39-40).

publisher: Mustafa al-Babi al-Halabi and Sons Library and Printing Company in Egypt
text:
Abu al-Salt became fed up with Egypt and the disappointment and hardship he encountered there. Al-Qifti said (1): "He entered Egypt in the days of its 'Afdal' (Best - pun on the Vizier's name) but received no favor from him, and he intended it for the 'Nile' (Nile/Obtaining) but found no attainment with him." Thus, he packed his bags for the Maghreb in the year 506 and restored his connection with the presence of Abu al-Tahir Yahya bin Tamim bin Badis, for whom he composed this "Egyptian Epistle."
In it, he describes what he witnessed in Egypt and what he suffered. He addressed in this valuable epistle:
1 - Geographical description of the Egyptian lands and its Nile.
2 - Then he began depicting the beauty of its quarters and dwellings, sometimes in poetry and other times in prose.
3 - He followed that by speaking about its inhabitants, their races, sects, morals, and beliefs, from the time of the Pharaohs to the advent of Islam.
4 - He then spoke about the wondrous monuments it contains, such as the two pyramids and the temples (Barabi).
5 - He mentioned the capitals of Egypt in ancient and modern times.
6 - The ancient scholars among the Greeks and Romans, digressing to the scarcity of those occupied with science, wisdom (philosophy), and medicine whom he met in Egypt.
7 - He marveled at the ignorance of the doctors he met there, while noting the merit of some skilled doctors.
8 - He spoke of the Egyptians' fondness for astrology and their frequent use of it, citing anecdotes and witticisms regarding that.
9 - He then turned to mentioning the men of letters and wits whom he met there.

This epistle connects to various sciences and arts, and is considered today, as it was considered
foot_note: 1. See Akhbar al-Ulama by Al-Qifti (p. 57), Sa'ada edition.

publisher: Mustafa al-Babi al-Halabi and Sons Library and Printing Company in Egypt
text:
yesterday, a document referred to by the geographer, historian, archaeologist, sociologist, philosopher, doctor, astrologer, and man of letters.
This small-sized but high-value epistle was known and circulated among great scholars and historians, then became rare and unknown, until the late scholar Ahmed Timur Pasha - may Allah rest his soul - was able to acquire it in his private library, under number 601 Literature. Upon this unique copy in the world - as becomes clear from checking Brockelmann's indexes (1) - I rely in publishing this unique epistle, parts of which were cited by Yaqut in *Irshad al-Arib*, Al-Imad in *Al-Kharidah*, Al-Qifti in *Ikhbar al-Ulama*, Ibn Abi Usaibia in *Uyun al-Anba*, Al-As'ad bin Mammati in *Qawanin al-Dawlah*, Al-Maqqari in *Nafh al-Tib*, Al-Maqrizi in *Al-Khitat*, Al-Adfuwi in *Al-Tali' al-Sa'id*, and Al-Suyuti in *Husn al-Muhadarah*, as will become clear to you upon the verification of its texts.

Abu al-Salt has works other than the Egyptian Epistle, such as *Kitab al-Hadiqa* (The Garden) in the style of *Yatimat al-Dahr* by Al-Tha'alibi, from which Al-Imad quoted in *Al-Kharidah*. He also has *Al-Adwiyah al-Mufrada* (Simple Drugs) preserved in the Bodleian Library; a *Treatise on Working with the Astrolabe* in Berlin, Leiden, and Bodleian; *Taqwim al-Dhihn* (Rectification of the Mind) in Logic at the Escorial Library; *Papers from a Book on Astronomy* at the Escorial; *Book on the Different Meanings of the Word 'Point'* in the Leiden Library; and a *Qasida* (Poem) in the Berlin Library.
foot_note: 1. See Brockelmann (1: 486 - 487) and his first supplement (p. 889). However, I later found a fragment of the Egyptian Epistle in the Egyptian National Library under number 354 History, and I will indicate its beginning and end in the footnotes.

text:
In the name of Allah, the Most Gracious, the Most Merciful

The Sheikh Abu al-Salt Umayyah bin Abd al-Aziz bin Abi al-Salt, may Allah Almighty have mercy on him, said:

I was, during the prime of youth, splendid, and the branch of boyhood was leafy.
*When my side-locks were black... and the water of my face had luster* (1)
Among those whom Time favored with one of its oversights, and overlooked during one of its naps, so he lived with a safe flock, pleasant drink, not vacating from literature whose gardens he grazed and whose pools he visited, except to entertainment whose arena he populated ???, dragging his tails and sleeves (in pride).

Then it (Time) changed color and turned the back of its shield to me, and gave me the dregs of its jar to drink. It rectified what it had neglected, and reclaimed what it had bestowed. I was compelled to leave the homeland, and depart from the resting place. I held back out of fear of leaving the first land my skin touched its soil, and upon which amulets were tied on me (2).

Matters came that were unbearable and great. When staying was no longer possible, and nothing remained but flight, I said: I have nothing left but to cast myself into every destination, and throw it into every place.
*To achieve an excuse or attain a desire... and a soul reaching its excuse is like a successful one* (3)
And I took comfort in the famous verse:
foot_note:
1. He borrowed it from the saying of Abu al-Tayyib al-Mutanabbi and modified it: 'And I wept over youth while my side-locks... were black and the water of my face had luster.'
2. Borrowed from the saying of Riqa' bin Qays al-Asadi: 'A land where amulets were tied on me... and the first land whose soil my skin touched.' Al-Lisan (Nawata) and Amali al-Qali (1: 83).
3. He also borrowed it from the saying of Urwah bin al-Ward, and Abu Tammam narrated it in Al-Hamasa (1: 188): 'And whoever is like me, possessing dependents and poor... of money, throws himself into every place. To reach an excuse or hit a desire... and a soul reaching its excuse is like a successful one.'

publisher: Mustafa al-Babi al-Halabi and Sons Library and Printing Company in Egypt
text:
*You will find in every land, if you settle in it... family for family and homelands for homelands* (1)
Even though the common people say: There is no lineage between one land and another; the best land is that which carries you.

So I began surveying the lands to aim for the most suitable for residence, and the most helpful in battling the days. Egypt was among what my choice fell upon, and I believed my good opinion before testing it. I traveled intending it, traversing the unknown deserts and wastelands, wading through perils and places of destruction.
Sometimes I mount every black-hided vessel (2), black-robed, steady like the dye of youth, its field widened, and its reins placed in the palm of the wind, so it ran the run of a recalcitrant horse, and surpassed the range of the ambitious glance.
And sometimes [I mount] every camel with callous flanks, like wolves (3), with long lips and curly hair, shod with cornelian or the split brother. If it ascends, you say an ostrich dyeing (its feathers), and if it descends, you say a piercing meteor. It connects gentle trotting with quick pacing (4), and the lowlands and highlands wore them out.
How many valley bends I traversed, and night robes I wore. How many lands I pierced their outlets and passes, and seas I split their crests and waves. I have no destination other than Egypt, nor a way beyond it, nor a quest for wealth short of it.
*And there are many lands on earth but... upon you, for my misery, my choice fell.*

When my mounts were submerged in the Nile, and sheltered in the shadow of Al-Muqattam, I threw down the staff of travel (settled), and the destination stabilized me. Their backs were lightened of saddles, and I rested them from solving and traveling. I said: My sought-after stray, and my intended desire; here I stay and reside,
foot_note:
1. The verse is from verses in Al-Hamasa (1: 98). Before it: 'Let not the ease of living in comfort prevent you... from the soul's longing for family and homelands.'
2. Meaning the ship.
3. Its flanks became callous only from continuous walking. Naqab here means: blistering of the skin. Hayatil: plural of Haytal, which is the wolf; the horse is likened to it in intensity of running. In the original: 'naqb al-ayatil kahayatil'.
4. The heard source of Wakhada is Wakhd and Wakhdan.

publisher: Mustafa al-Babi al-Halabi and Sons Library and Printing Company in Egypt
text:
so I do not leave nor depart, «with a good land and a forgiving Lord». Where I turned, there was a garden and a brook, a Khawarnaq and a Sadir (palaces), a shading shade, and a gentle breeze.
*How I wished to meet within it someone... who consoles from worry or aids against calamities* (1)
*But I found only people who, if they spoke truth... their promises were like a mirage in lying* (2)
*And I had a means I thought I would... benefit from, but behold, my disease was from the means*
*So nothing clips my nails but my pen... nor are the battalions of my enemies anything but my books* (3)

The duration of stay did not lengthen until I realized, by what I witnessed, that I am therein of diminished merchandise, degenerate craft, singled out for insult and waste; and that its easy life is restricted to the scoundrel, and its bitter punishment is reserved for the free man. Had I advanced and known that, my vehicle would have lightened from it (4) and I would have turned the face of my quest to other than it. I would have had a vast scope in the earth, and a wide resort. But I was hindered, until I was entangled, until I was treated as those of crimes and sins are treated, and I gulped from humiliation a full bucket.
This is despite what I composed of panegyrics that became famous as the morning, blew like the winds, and the camel-driver and sailor became fond of (5).
*So he who does not walk briskly traveled with them... and he who does not sing chirping sang with them*
Except that Allah, exalted be His blessings and holy be His names, rectified with His mercy, so He removed that ordeal with a gift, and abrogated that vengeance with a blessing, and concluded with the arrival at the presence of the Grand King Abu al-Tahir Yahya bin Tamim bin al-Muizz bin Badis, whose presence never ceased to be the destination
foot_note:
1. In the original: 'min al-nub' (from calamities), its correction is in Yaqut (7: 80), Al-Qifti (57), and Ibn Abi Usaibia (2: 60). He borrowed these verses from old poetry of his, as understood from Ibn Abi Usaibia's narration.
2. In the original: 'ka-al-alf' (like the thousand), its correction is in Yaqut, Al-Qifti, and Ibn Abi Usaibia.
3. In the original 'kata'ib a'wani' (battalions of my helpers), and the correction is from the references.
4. In the original: 'fakhaffa' (so it lightened).
5. See his praise for Al-Afdal in Ibn Abi Usaibia (2: 56).

publisher: Mustafa al-Babi al-Halabi and Sons Library and Printing Company in Egypt
text:
of captives (1), the desire of seekers, the gathering place of virtues, the resort of the virtuous, the watering place of generosity, and the ritual site of delegations.
When I hid under his wing, and sought support in his benevolence, he sweetened for me the fruit of Time with his generosity, and apologized to me for what it (Time) had committed. He held back its palm from me, and diverted its vicissitudes from me.
*A generous one whom I rejected people when I reached him... as if they were what lightened from a traveler's provision*
So I was, in what I went through, and what my state turned to, of shining after setting, and leafing after withering, like a blade whose matter was neglected due to ignorance of its worth. When it fell to the one expert in it, he maintained its blade alone, and ornamented its straps and sheath, then stored it among what is stored and prepared. If he unsheathed it one day, he approved of it; if he stripped it, he praised it; and if he shook it, its cutting in the struck object pleased him.
But Allah refused that merit belongs except to one who grew up in its planting grounds, rose in its origins, was raised in its bosom, and was fed by its full moon.
*So I did not find palatable except his dew, so there was not... to equal in my eyes this precinct, any precinct*
*For not every favor is light to bear... even if white clouds rained from it upon me* (2)
*But the most glorious deed is what its owner came with... and no door or veil came before it*
*I wished only to guide those blaming me... that my opinion in loving you is correct* (3)
*And I teach a people who opposed me so they went east... and I went west, that I have succeeded and they failed*

It is better that I turn away from what has passed, leave what preceded, and take to what I have proceeded towards and intended, aimed for and relied upon, of what the High Presence (4) - may Allah prolong its height - preferred, of describing what I suffered of the land of Egypt and witnessed, and restricting to what I saw rather than what I narrated. For he who says: 'I knew this by way of knowledge and hearing' is not like one who says: 'I verified it by witnessing and observation.' For the honest person of intellect is not deceived by impossibility, nor pleased with plagiarism.
I begin by mentioning these lands, their location in the inhabited world, the course of the Nile in them, and its sufficiency therein. I append to that a summary of mentioning the conditions of its people regarding their morals, biographies, and customs, and what connects to that, is dragged along with it, comes because of it, and enters into its folds.
Here I am beginning that, seeking help from Allah, and upon Him is reliance. (1)
foot_note:
1. Masad: Place of hunting. 'Anah: Plural of 'Anin, meaning captive/prisoner.
2. Rabab: Clouds that ride upon one another, singular Rababa. In original: 'lada wa la minhu alayya', corrected from Yaqut (7: 59), and its rhyme there is 'sahab'.
3. The verse and the one following it are by Al-Mutanabbi in his Diwan (1: 127) narrated by Al-Ukbari.
4. In the original: 'Al-Shamiyya' (The Levantine).

text:
The entire land of Egypt is located in the inhabited world within the sections of the Second Clime and the Third Clime, mostly in the Third. Those concerned with its news and histories recounted that its boundary in longitude (2) is from the city of Barqa, which is in the south of the Roman Sea (Mediterranean), to Ayla on the coast of the gulf issuing from the Sea of Abyssinia, Zanj, India, and China (Red Sea). The distance of that is nearly forty days.
They said: Its boundary in latitude is from the city of Aswan and what aligns with it of Upper Egypt adjacent to the land of Nubia, to Rashid (Rosetta) (3) and what aligns with it of the Nile's outlets into the Roman Sea. The distance of that is nearly thirty days.
It is bordered from its beginning in latitude to its end by two mountains [one on the eastern bank of the Nile, which is Al-Muqattam, and the other on the western bank of it. The Nile flows between them. They are (4)] barren, not lofty, approaching each other
foot_note:
1. The speech from here to the word 'straightness' was quoted by Al-Maqrizi in (1: 15-16).
2. This is a historical geographic record of what Egypt's borders were in his era.
3. In the original: 'to the land of Sham and Rashid', corrected from Al-Khitat.
4. Completion from Al-Khitat.

publisher: Mustafa al-Babi al-Halabi and Sons Library and Printing Company in Egypt
text:
very closely in their positions, from the city of Aswan until it ends at Fustat. There, the distance between them widens and they separate slightly. Al-Muqattam takes an eastern direction and the other a western one, diverging in their paths (1) and separating (2) in their courses. So the land of Egypt widens from Fustat to the coast of the Roman Sea upon which are Al-Farama (3), Tinnis, Damietta, Rashid, and Alexandria. There it ends in its latitude, which is the distance [between] its furthest point in the south and [its furthest] in the west and north.
If measured by the demonstrative method in the path of this distance [in miles (4)], it does not reach thirty miles (5), rather it falls short of it by a negligible amount. That is because the difference between the latitude of Aswan, which is its furthest point in the south, and the latitude of the city of Tinnis, which is its furthest point in the north, is nine degrees and about a sixth of a degree of the degrees by which the Great Circle encompasses, [which are (6)] three hundred and sixty degrees. There is no difference between their longitudes that causes a significant amount in this calculation. If we multiply this number by what pertains to one degree of aligning that in miles, which is fifty-six miles and two-thirds of a mile according to what the proof indicated, that would be (7) about five hundred and twenty miles approximately. That is a distance of a twenty-day march or close to that (8). In this duration of time, the traveler always traverses what is between these two towns at a moderate pace in a little more than that, due to the winding of the road and lack of straightness (9).
foot_note:
1. In Al-Khitat: 'ma'khadahuma' (their taking points).
2. In the original: 'wa ta'rij' (and winding), corrected in Al-Khitat.
3. In the original: 'Al-Haraman' (The Two Pyramids), corrected from Al-Khitat.
4. This completion and the one before it are from Al-Khitat.
5. In the original: 'yawman' (day), and its explanation is what I established from Al-Khitat.
6. Not in the original.
7. In the original: 'min dhalik' (from that).
8. Quoted in Al-Nujum al-Zahirah (1: 36) that it is thirty days.

publisher: Mustafa al-Babi al-Halabi and Sons Library and Printing Company in Egypt
text:
The land of Egypt does not contain, after Fustat which is the seat of the King and the throne of the State, cities of significance in number or grandeur. However, its greatest and most proud cities are: in the northern direction from Fustat, Alexandria, Tinnis, and Damietta; and in the southern direction to the furthest Upper Egypt, Qus and Qift. This is the description of the land of Egypt in general. (1)
As for the Nile, its source is beyond the Equator, from a mountain there known as the Mountain of the Moon (Jabal al-Qamar). It begins to increase in the month of Abib (2), which is July (3) in Roman. The Egyptians say: "If Abib enters, the water has a creep (dabib)." Upon its beginning to increase (4), all its qualities change and spoil. The reason necessitating this is its passing through stagnant pools of water (5) which it mixes with, pulls, and extracts with it, accompanying them, among other possibilities (6).
It becomes like the state described by Prince Tamim bin Al-Muizz li-Din Allah:
*Do you not see the thunder cried and complained... and the lightning flashed and laughed?* (7)
*So drink upon a cloud like the dye of darkness... that made the face of the earth laugh when it cried* (8)
*[The Oud imitated the moan of passion... but it excelled in what it imitated]* (9)
foot_note:
1. From here begins another quotation by Al-Maqrizi in (1: 59).
2. In Al-Khitat: 'Al-Tazayud'. 'Al-Tazayyud' and 'Al-Tazayud' have the same meaning.
3. What follows 'Abib' is not in Al-Khitat. In the original: 'Qawliyah'.
4. In Al-Khitat: 'Al-Tazayud'.
5. In the original: 'bi-naqa' ma'a miyah ajinah', correction in Al-Khitat.
6. The speech and poetry after this were not cited by Al-Maqrizi.
7. In the original: 'The atmosphere from its darkness has complained', and the meter does not fit, as it is from Al-Sari'. I established what is in Diwan Tamim Folio (120) from the photocopy of Dar al-Kutub number (16025 Z). This version is what Al-Tha'alibi mentioned in Yatimat al-Dahr (1: 349) First Edition.
8. In the original: 'yushbih al-tahqiq ka-subh' corruption, I established what is in the Diwan and Yatimat al-Dahr.
9. Proof of this verse from Diwan Tamim.

publisher: Mustafa al-Babi al-Halabi and Sons Library and Printing Company in Egypt
text:
*And look at the Nile water in its rise... as if it were sandalwood or musk*
Or as another of the contemporaries said, from a poem describing the land of Egypt:
*And to God belongs the flow of the Nile in it when the East Wind... showed us in its passage a dragged army* (1)
*So a bank shaking the Samhari (spears) withered... and a wave shaking the white (swords) of India turning to gold*
*When it rises it mimics the rose fresh, and if it clears... it mimics its water in color but does not surpass it in scent* (2)
This is similar to what Abdullah bin Sariya recited to me of his own:
*The river pleased me with purity... after my longing for its purity*
*It was like the rose fresh... then it became like its water*
And by Abu Bakr Al-Sanawbari (3) in a similar meaning:
*I was moved by the Euphra... tes with every possessor of generosity and glory*
*And the sun at its setting... is yellow, gilding the sword-sheen*
*And the water, its two edges... are green from myrtle and rand* (4)
*The hands of the wind gift it if... they blow from near and far*
*With novelties of silver... and novelties of lapis lazuli*
*And the ships like birds darted... in the air in pairs and singles*
*Until when the Euphra... tes ebbed, it passed and followed it with a flow* (5)
foot_note:
1. A great army is called 'Majr', due to its weight and bulk.
2. Mimicked its water, meaning resembled rose water in color. In the original: 'haka ma'uhu naflam' corruption.
3. He is Abu Bakr Ahmed bin Muhammad bin Al-Hasan bin Al-Marrar, known as Al-Sanawbari Al-Halabi. Al-Sam'ani said in Folio (355): attributed to pine (Sanawbar). See another explanation in Mukhtasar Tarikh Dimashq (1: 456). His death was in 334 AH as in Shadharat al-Dhahab. See Fawat al-Wafiyat (1: 77).
4. Rand: A tree of the desert trees with a good scent, and myrtle is called 'Rand'. In the original: 'wurud' (roses), which has no basis.
5. In the original: 'bi-ward' (with rose), and the explanation is what I established.

publisher: Mustafa al-Babi al-Halabi and Sons Library and Printing Company in Egypt
text:
*I saw it as if... a robe of roses was thrown upon it*
*Restless like the lover... whose beloved announced rejection*
*As if in its bowels is what... is in my bowels of anxiety and passion*
And Tamim Al-Muizz said, and improved the comparison (1):
*A day for us by the Nile short... and every day of joy is short*
*The ships ascend like horses with us... therein, and the army of water descends*
*As if its waves are chambers... and as if its eddies are beds*
And Muhammad bin Al-Hasan said:
*The river is clothed in flowers... an elegant garment like a robe... running with musk or melted gold* (2)
*If it straightens you see the flat of a blade... and if it rounds you see the curve of a bracelet*
And Abu al-Hasan Muhammad bin al-Wazir said, regarding the gradual increase of the water finger by finger, and the benefit of that graduation:
*I see always much from little... and a full moon in reality from a crescent*
*So do not wonder, for every little water... in Egypt is a cause for a gulf of money*
*An increase of a finger every day... is an increase of cubits in good condition*
When it reaches sixteen cubits and increases by one finger from the sixteenth, the Canal (Khalij) is broken (3). Its breaking has a counted day, a witnessed occasion, and a crowded gathering attended by the common and the elite. When it is broken, the canals (Tura') - which are the mouths of the gulfs - are opened, so the water overflows
foot_note:
1. I did not find the following verses in Diwan Tamim.
2. In the original: 'yajri li-sakk dhawb nudar'.
3. In the original: 'nafa'at naf'an 'aziman' (benefited greatly), and I established what is in Al-Maqrizi (1: 59).

publisher: Mustafa al-Babi al-Halabi and Sons Library and Printing Company in Egypt
text:
and spreads, covering the fields and plains (1). People retreat to their highest dwellings of estates and houses, which are on hills and mounds that the water does not reach, nor does the flood dominate. At that point, the land of Egypt entirely becomes a submerging sea between its two mountains bordering it. It remains in this state until it reaches the limited bound, by the will of the Worshipped Lord. Most of that hovers around eighteen cubits. Then it begins returning to its outlet, to the course of the Nile [and its path, so it recedes first from what was (2)] of the land overlooking and high, and becomes in what was low of it (3), leaving every depression like a dirham, and abandoning every hillock like a striped garment.
At this time of the year, the land of Egypt is the most beautiful thing to behold, especially its famous parks and frequented monasteries, like Al-Jazirah, Birkat al-Habash (4), and similar places frequented by people of leisure, and visited by people of literature and mirth.
It happened that we went out in such a time to Birkat al-Habash. We spread from its flowers the best carpet, and shaded ourselves from its trees with the fullest canopy. Suns rose upon us from the glass of cups in the robes of full moons, and stars (5) illuminated with purity, until the gold of the afternoon flowed onto the silver of the water, and the fire of twilight clung to the coal of darkness. So one of us (6) said regarding that:
foot_note:
1. In Al-Khitat: 'and submerged the bottoms and plains'.
2. The place of this completion which I established from Al-Khitat is blank in the original.
3. Instead of this sentence in the original: '... mutahaffiz ... nistamiyan', and its completion and correction from Al-Khitat.
4. It was outside the city of Fustat to its south between the Nile and the Mountain. It was named Birkat al-Habash (Abyssinians' Lake) after Qatadah bin Qays bin Habashi al-Sadafi, who witnessed the conquest of Egypt, and had gardens next to this lake known as Al-Habash, so the lake was attributed to it. The location of this lake today is the agricultural land area belonging to the village of Deir al-Tin, and a great part of the agricultural lands belonging to the village of Al-Basatin. See Al-Khitat (2: 152) and Al-Nujum al-Zahirah (5: 14).
5. In the original: 'wujum' (sulkiness).
6. Meaning himself. It states in Al-Khitat (2: 155): "Ibn Saeed said in the book Al-Maghrib: 'I went out once where Birkat al-Habash is, about which Abu al-Salt Umayyah bin Abd al-Aziz al-Andalusi - may Allah pardon him - says'." And he recited the following verses. It states in (2: 160): "Bir Abi Salamah, known as Bir al-Ghanam, is south of Al-Nubiyya, and its location is the best spot in the lake, and it is what Abu al-Salt Umayyah bin Abd al-Aziz meant by his saying." And he recited the verses, and Yaqut narrated them in Umayyah's biography attributed to him.

publisher: Mustafa al-Babi al-Halabi and Sons Library and Printing Company in Egypt
text:
*By God, my day at Birkat al-Habash... while the horizon was between light and dusk*
*And the Nile under the winds was agitated... like a sharp sword in the right hand of a trembling one*
*The hand of the clouds wove it for us... so we are upon carpets from its weaving*
*And we are in a garden adorned... rain embroidered its sides and embellished* (1)
*So hand me the wine, for the leaver of it... is not revived from the assault of worry*
*And water me with large cups filled... for they are most quenching for severe thirst* (2)
*The heaviest of all people is a man... whom the caller of youth called but he did not fly (with joy)* (3)
He also said:
*Distract your heart with pleasures and mirth... and hurry to the wine with goals and select drinks*
*Do you not see the lush Lake wearing... embroidery of lights woven by the hand of clouds*
*And it became, from fresh plants, in robes... rain revealed from it every hidden thing*
*From lilies whose eyes choked with dew... and chamomile desiring dark lips and coolness*
*And look at the rose mimicking the cheek of a modest one... from narcissus remaining to show the glance of a watcher*
*And jasmine has exceeded pearls... and the wine is pearls floating on gold*
*How many times we cured our burning thirst in it... with a blazing coal from the mouth of the pitcher* (4)
*A sun of wine greeted us by a moon... overlooking a branch shaking nearby*
*He loosened his side-locks, and swayed bending... like the spear shaft, with black hair ends*
*So rejoice and take it, drink, for the motives of fun and mirth have called... upon youthfulness*
And among what relates to describing the Nile are verses he wrote to Al-Afdal on the night of the Mahrajan (Festival):
foot_note:
1. In the original: 'dhabaha bi-l-qatr' (slaughtered with rain), corrected from Al-Khitat and Mu'jam al-Udaba.
2. In the original: 'la'alla arwa' (perhaps most quenching). In Mu'jam al-Udaba: 'fahunna ashfa' (for they are most healing).
3. In the original: 'yad'uhu da'i al-siba' (the caller of youth calls him), I established what is in Al-Khitat and Mu'jam al-Udaba.
4. In the original: 'illatina' (our illness) with 'Ain.

publisher: Mustafa al-Babi al-Halabi and Sons Library and Printing Company in Egypt
text:
*You invented for people a wondrous sight... may you continue to revive joy and mirth*
*You reconciled opposites capably... so he who saw the water saw it mixing with flame*
*As if the Nile and the candles upon it... were the horizon of a sky shining with meteors*
*It was of silver then became a sky... and you think the fire upon it is gold*
Poets have taken turns ..... rays on a morning [*]. Among the pleasant things said in that is the saying of some of the contemporaries, Abu al-Hasan Ali bin Abi al-Bishr the Scribe:
*We drank at sunset a sun... diluted until the time of rising*
*And the light of candles upon the Nile appearing... like the tips of spears in shields*
Abu Mansur Al-Tha'alibi recited (in Yatimat al-Dahr) by Mansur bin Kayghalagh (1):
*The boy stood circulating it in his palm... so I thought the full moon was carrying a star*
*And the moon tends towards setting as if... a gilded sword was drawn over the bank* (2)
And he recited in it (3) by Judge Abu al-Qasim Ali bin Ibrahim bin Abi al-Fahm Al-Tanukhi:
*How beautiful is the Tigris while darkness pours down... and the moon in the horizon of the sky is setting*
*As if it is therein a blue carpet... and as if there is upon it a gilded embroidery* (4)
And Ibn Waki' Al-Tinnisi said:
*A pool whose waves are folded by... the blowing of the North wind and the passing of the East wind*
*When the sun shines from above it... you imagine it a gilded breastplate*
foot_note:
1. In Part One of Yatimat al-Dahr (p. 65). Before the two verses: 'Time returned with whom I loved so he blamed... O my two friends, give me drink and drink. How many nights I conversed with its moon... above the Tigris before he absented.'
2. In the original: 'fawq al-lahz' (above the glance), and in Al-Yatimah: 'fawq al-ma'' (above the water). See what follows in the poetry of Ibn al-Tammar al-Wasiti.
3. i.e., in this meaning or in the book Yatimat al-Dahr. See Al-Yatimah (1:65).
4. In the original: 'wa ka'annahu fihi tiraz', the explanation is what I established from Al-Yatimah. [*] (Shamela Comment): The complete phrase as it appeared in Al-Kharidah: 'Poets have taken turns describing the falling of rays on the surface of the water.' [Noted in the Addendum]

publisher: Mustafa al-Babi al-Halabi and Sons Library and Printing Company in Egypt
text:
And some of the contemporaries said in a poem:
*Bati' Nahr Kana Al-Ra... while the silver in it melted* (1)
*If the East wind scratched it you saw it... as if it were a gilded chainmail* [*]
Abu Ubadah Al-Buhturi said describing a pool:
*If the East wind rises over it, it reveals in it ripples... like breastplates with polished edges* (2)
*If the stars appear in its sides... at night you think a sky was installed in it*
Abdullah bin al-Mu'tazz excelled in his saying:
*And a watery (river) appeared to them in Najaf... clear of pools, glued (cold)* (3)
*When a pearl of sun faced it... you thought jewelry was broken upon it* (4)
Ibn al-Tammar al-Wasiti said describing the moonlight on the Tigris:
*Stand and take justice from the vicissitudes of Time and calamities... and gather with your cup the union of fun and mirth*
*Do you not see the night, its armies have turned away... defeated, and the armies of fun are in pursuit*
*And the moon in the western horizon you think... has extended a bridge over the two banks of gold*
Muhammad bin Abdullah Al-Salami said:
*And a river where waves frolic... the frolicking of horses in the dust of battle*
*When the sun turns yellow upon it we imagine... the fresh water is mixed with wine*
***
As for the inhabitants of the land of Egypt, they are mixtures of people of different categories (5): Copts, Romans, Arabs, Berbers, Kurds, Daylam, Abyssinians, Armenians (6), and others of
foot_note:
1. Thus the two verses appeared with their corruption.
2. The two verses are from a poem praising Al-Mutawakkil and describing his pool. Diwan 319.
3. Al-Ghari: Cold. It is said 'Ghariya al-ghadir': its water became cold.
4. In Diwan Ibn al-Mu'tazz 61: 'fa-idha dahakat-hu' (if it laughed at it).
5. In Al-Khitat (1:48): 'mukhtalifu al-asnaf' (different in categories).
6. This word is not in Al-Khitat. [*] (Shamela Comment): The two verses as in Al-Kharidah: 'By the bank of a river as if glass... and the purity of silver in it melted. If the East wind scratched it in the forenoon... you imagined it a gilded chainmail.' See p. 116 of Nawadir al-Makhtutat. [Noted in the Addendum]

publisher: Mustafa al-Babi al-Halabi and Sons Library and Printing Company in Egypt
text:
categories and races according to their differences. They said: The reason for their difference, and the cause of their mixing, is the mixing of those who owned it and conquered it, from the Amalekites, Greeks, Romans, Arabs, and others. For this reason, their lineages mixed, so they contented themselves in identifying themselves by attributing to their places (1), and belonging to their birthplaces and locations.
A group of historians recounted that in past times they were idol worshippers and managers of temples, until the religion of Christianity appeared and prevailed over the land of Egypt, so they became Christians. They remained so until the Muslims conquered it in the days of Umar bin Al-Khattab, may Allah be pleased with him. Some of them became Muslim and some remained on the religion of Christianity, and their sect is the Jacobite sect.
As for their morals, predominant among them is following desires, indulging in pleasures, busying themselves with trifles, believing impossibilities, and weakness of resolve and determination, among other things that Abu al-Hussein Ali bin Ridwan recounted and narrated, citing natural causes for it (2). He suffices as a fair judge and a just witness.
Al-Wasifi recounted in his book which he authored on the news of Egypt that its people in former times believed that this world, which is the world of generation and corruption, remained for a period of time empty of the human species, inhabited by other species than humans. And that those species were different in singular creations (3) and odd forms. Then the human species occurred and disputed with those species, overcame them, seized control, exterminated most of them by killing, and chased the remainder to the wastelands. Those chased ones are the Ghouls and Succubi (Si'lat) and others, among what he recounted of their impossible beliefs, corrupt conceptions, and repulsive delusions. However, it appears from
foot_note:
1. In Al-Khitat: 'by pointing to their places'.
2. The word appeared thus.
3. Al-Fadhdha: Singular/Unique. In the Hadith: 'This singular verse', meaning unique in its meaning.

publisher: Mustafa al-Babi al-Halabi and Sons Library and Printing Company in Egypt
text:
their affair that there was a group among them possessing knowledge and sciences, especially the science of Geometry and Astronomy (1). Evidence for that is what they left behind of wondrous miraculous works (2), like the Pyramids and Temples (Barabi), for they are among the monuments that bewildered the [penetrating] minds (3) [and incapacitated weighing thoughts], and left them busy wondering at them and thinking about them. Regarding such things, Abu al-Ala Ahmed bin Suleiman Al-Ma'arri says in his poem eulogizing his father (4):
*The tombs mislead the minds regarding their guidance... nor is the upright opinion safe from error*
*The masters of eloquence whenever... they saw beauty counted it as the work of Jinn*
What is more amazing and strange, after the capabilities and creations of Allah, than the ability to build a [colossal (5)] body from the greatest stones, square in base, conical in shape, the height of its pillar being three hundred and about seventeen cubits (6), surrounded by four triangular surfaces with equal sides, the length of each side being four hundred and sixty cubits (7). Despite this magnitude (8), and the precision of craftsmanship and perfection (9), it is in the utmost good estimation such that it has not been affected (10) until now and so forth (11) by the blowing of winds, the pouring of clouds,
foot_note:
1. In Al-Khitat (1: 118): 'and especially the science of Geometry and Astronomy'.
2. In Al-Khitat: 'of crafts'.
3. In the original: 'The monuments far from minds', corrected from Al-Khitat.
4. In Saqt al-Zand (1: 196) with Al-Tanwir commentary.
5. This is from Al-Khitat.
6. In Al-Khitat: 'nineteen cubits'. Cubit (Dhra') can be masculine or feminine.
7. In Al-Nujum al-Zahirah (1: 98) quoting Abu al-Salt: 'and seventy cubits'.
8. In the original: 'with this length of it' and written next to it: 'in magnitude' instead of 'length of it'. I established what is in Al-Khitat.
9. Instead in Al-Khitat: 'and perfection of geometry (Hindam)'.
10. In the original: 'and it is not affected', I established what is in Al-Khitat.
11. Thus appeared in the Original and Al-Khitat. Perhaps: 'to this day and so forth'.

publisher: Mustafa al-Babi al-Halabi and Sons Library and Printing Company in Egypt
text:
and the shaking of earthquakes. This is the description of each of the two pyramids adjacent to Fustat on the western side, according to what we witnessed of them (1). Some said, mentioning the wonders of Egypt: "There is no structure on the face of the earth except that I pity it from the night and day, except the two pyramids, for I pity the night and day from them."
These two pyramids (2) have an overlooking upon the land of Egypt, a towering [over] its plains, and an ascension to its peaks. They are what Abu al-Tayyib al-Mutanabbi meant by his saying:
*Where is the one whose building the pyramids are... What is his people, what is his day, what is the death spot* (3)
*We used to think his abodes filled... with gold, but he died and every house is a wasteland* (4)
*Monuments remain behind their lords... for a time, then ruin overtakes them and they follow* (5)
It happened that we went out one day to them. When we circled them and turned around them, our wonder at them increased, so we exchanged words about them. One of us said (6):
*By your life, have you seen a more amazing sight... throughout what you have seen than the two pyramids of Egypt* (7)
*[They towered reaching for the sky and overlooked... the atmosphere like the overlooking of Arcturus or Vega (8)*
foot_note:
1. In the original: 'minha' (of it), corrected in Al-Khitat.
2. In the original: 'I pity the night and day from them upon and these two pyramids are among the greatest of them.' I established the correction from Al-Khitat.
3. From a poem in his Diwan (1: 405) with Al-Ukbari's commentary, eulogizing Abu Shuja' Fatik.
4. This verse was not cited by Al-Maqrizi, and it is here out of its natural place. Its place in the Diwan is after a verse following the third here; because the pronoun of 'his abodes' refers to Abu Shuja' in the referenced verse, which is: 'A limit did not satisfy the heart of Abu Shuja'... before death and no place contained him.'
5. In Al-Khitat: 'behind their inhabitants'. In the Diwan: 'behind their owners'.
6. In Bada'i' al-Bada'ah 136, the one who said the poetry is Abu al-Salt himself.
7. After this in the original is a blank space of about two pages. I managed to fill this gap from what Al-Maqrizi quoted in Al-Khitat (1: 118-119): I placed this missing part between completion brackets: [. . . . .].
8. In Bada'i' al-Bada'ah: 'They towered in the sides of the sky'.

publisher: Mustafa al-Babi al-Halabi and Sons Library and Printing Company in Egypt
text:
*And they fulfilled a high prominence from the earth... as if they were two breasts rising on a chest]* (1)
A group claimed that the pyramids are tombs of great kings, who preferred to be distinguished by them from other kings after their death, just as they were distinguished from them in their lives, and intended for their memory to remain because of them over the passage of eras and the lapse of ages.
When Caliph Al-Ma'mun arrived in Egypt (2), he ordered them breached. One of the two pyramids adjacent to Fustat was breached after severe effort and long trouble. They found inside it pits and ascents whose matter was terrifying and passage difficult. They found at its top a cubic room, the length of each of its sides about eight cubits, and in its center a marble basin covered. When its lid was removed, they found nothing in it but a decayed corpse, upon which bygone eras had passed. Thereupon Al-Ma'mun ordered to desist from breaching the other. It is said: The expense on breaching it was great, and the cost severe.
Among people are those who claimed that Hermes the First, called the Triply-Blessed with Prophecy, Kingship, and Wisdom - who is the one the Hebrews call Enoch son of Jared son of Mahalalel son of Kenan son of Enos son of Seth son of Adam, peace be upon him, and he is Idris peace be upon him - deduced from the conditions of the stars that the Flood would cover the earth. So he increased the building of pyramids, and depositing wealth and sheets of knowledge in them, and what he feared would be lost and erased, to preserve them and protect them.
It is said: The one who built them was a king named Surid bin Sahluq bin Siryaq. Others said: The one who built the two pyramids adjacent to Fustat was Shaddad bin Ad, due to a vision he saw. The Copts deny the entry of the Amalekites into the land of Egypt,
foot_note:
1. After it in Bada'i' al-Bada'ah: 'Abu Mansur Zafir al-Haddad composed: Contemplate the shape of the two pyramids and look... and between them is the wondrous Sphinx. Like two camel-litters on a journey... with two lovers and between them a watcher. And the overflow of the sea between them is tears... and the sound of the wind between them is weeping. And outward looks Joseph's prison is like a lover... left behind, so he is sad and depressed.'
2. That was in the year 217 as in history books.

publisher: Mustafa al-Babi al-Halabi and Sons Library and Printing Company in Egypt
text:
and verify that their builder was Surid (1), for a vision he saw, which was that a calamity would descend from the sky, which is the Flood. They said he built them in a period of six months, and covered them with colored silk brocade, and wrote on them: "We built them in six months. Tell him who comes after us to demolish them in six hundred years; for demolishing is easier than building. And we covered them in colored silk, so let him cover them in mats, for mats are easier than silk."
We saw the surfaces of each of these two pyramids inscribed from top to bottom with tight parallel lines, from the writing of their builder; their letters are not known today, nor are their meanings understood.
In summary, the matter regarding them is amazing, such that the utmost description of them and exaggeration in expression falls short of the reality of the described, unlike what [Ali (2)] bin al-Abbas al-Rumi said, even if the described objects are far apart and the intentions different, when he says:
*If you describe a person to a person... do not exaggerate in his description and be moderate*
*For if you exaggerate, you drive suspicio... ns regarding him to the furthest purpose*
*So he becomes small where you magnified him... due to the merit of the absent over the witnessed*
The same applies to the Temples (Barabi), such as the Temple of Akhmim, the Temple of Samanoud (3), and the Temple of Dendera (4). For in them is precision, quality of form, and beauty of imagery, which indicates that their builders
foot_note:
1. In Al-Nujum al-Zahirah: 'Suwayrid and said Suwayd'.
2. Here ends the gap I noted in Footnote 7 of page 26.
3. In the original: 'Samandu', corrected from Al-Maqrizi when mentioning the Barabi. Yaqut said: 'The Samanudi district had a Barba which was one of the wonders. Al-Quda'i said: It was mentioned from Abu Amr al-Kindi that he said: I saw it while some of its workers stored acacia leaves (Qaraz) in it. I saw the camel when it approached its door and wanted to enter, every crawling insect in the Qaraz fell, and nothing entered the Barba. Then it was ruined around three hundred and fifty.'
4. In the original: 'Didar', but it is 'Dendera', or 'Dandara', or 'Andara' as in Mu'jam al-Buldan. Regarding the Temple of Dendera, Al-Maqrizi says: 'It is a wondrous temple, having one hundred and eighty windows; the sun enters every day from one window, then the second until it reaches the last, then returns to the place of its start.' Yaqut recited in the opening of verses: 'If a judge in Dendera... said two lines he wrote.'

publisher: Mustafa al-Babi al-Halabi and Sons Library and Printing Company in Egypt
text:
were possessors of weighing minds, and that they had extreme care for Wisdom (philosophy/science), especially the crafts of Geometry and Astronomy.
Some of those concerned with the news of nations and their histories said: There were in Egypt after the Flood scholars in types of Wisdom, of Mathematical, Natural, and Divine sciences, and verifiers in the science of Burning Mirrors, Talismans, Magic (Niranjiyat), and other things.
Kingship in Egypt from ancient times was in the city of Memphis, which is to the west of the Nile, at a distance of twelve miles from Fustat. When Alexander built the city of (Alexandria) about one thousand four hundred and forty years ago, people desired to inhabit it (1), and it was the abode of science and the seat of wisdom, until the Muslims conquered it in the caliphate of Umar bin Al-Khattab, may Allah be pleased with him. Amr bin Al-Aas laid out his city known as (Fustat), so the people of Egypt and others from Arabs and non-Arabs flowed to inhabit it, so it became the capital of the lands of Egypt and its center to this time of ours.
It is said that among the ancient people of science in it was Hermes the Third (2). He was a philosopher roaming the lands, touring cities, knowledgeable of their configuration (3), their horoscopes, and the natures of their people. He has majestic useful writings in arts of wisdom.
Among them is Diophantus (4), author of the treatises set down in the science of Number and its properties by way of Algebra and Muqabala.
foot_note:
1. In the original: 'and marveled at building it', corrected from Al-Maqrizi (1: 135).
2. In the original: 'Hermes the Second', corrected as established from Uyun al-Anba by Ibn Abi Usaibia (1: 17) where he mentioned the three Hermes, and said regarding this Hermes: 'As for Hermes the Third, he lived in the city of Egypt, and was after the Flood.' As for Hermes the Second, he was Chaldean from the people of Babylon. Hermes the First was Egyptian before the Flood, and he is Idris peace be upon him to the Arabs.
3. In the original: 'bi-nasbiha' (its fraud/erection), and in Uyun al-Anba: 'knowledgeable of the configuration (nasbah) of cities and their natures'.
4. Ibn Abi Usaibia mentioned him in (1: 245) during the biography of 'Qusta bin Luqa', saying: 'Book on translating Diophantus in Algebra and Muqabala': He also mentioned him incidentally in the biography of Ibn al-Haytham (2: 98).

publisher: Mustafa al-Babi al-Halabi and Sons Library and Printing Company in Egypt
text:
Among them is Al-Iskandarani (The Alexandrian) (1), author of the Book of Spheres and the Book of Canon in the Almanac of Stars.
Among them is Rosim (2), author of classifications in Alchemy.
Among them is Anqilaus the Alexandrian (3) and his companions, who summarized Galen's books in the craft of Medicine, and composed them by way of question and answer; their good summarization indicates their abundant knowledge and excess of understanding.
Among them is Valens (4), author of the book known as the Roman Bridge (Al-Baridj), classified in Nativities and what precedes them of Introduction to the science of Astrology judgments. It is said that he is the one who extracted, through long investigation (5) and continuous effort, the horoscopes of the Egyptians.
These are the famous people of Wisdom in Egypt in that time. As for this time of ours, every science in it has been obliterated, its trace erased, and its name ignored. Nothing remains but riffraff, scum, ignorant masses, and blind commoners. Most of them are people of foolishness (6), having experience in cunning and plotting,
foot_note:
1. Perhaps 'Oktemon the Alexandrian'. Al-Qifti said in Akhbar al-Hukama (50): 'He was knowledgeable in mathematics, verifier of observations, expert in making their instruments.' He and Meton gathered for observation in the city of Alexandria in Egypt, observed and recorded what they verified, and scholars circulated it after them until the time of Ptolemy Claudius the Observer in Alexandria. 'Their time was five hundred and seventy-one years before his time.'
2. Al-Qifti mentioned him on p. 127, as 'Rosham'. He said: 'Rosham the Egyptian, this man was in Egypt before Islam, and is an expert in the sciences of Alchemy, its origins, details, and precision of its composition... and he has majestic books on that famous among scholars of this type who compete to acquire and obtain them.'
3. Al-Qifti wrote his biography in (51-52) and Ibn Abi Usaibia in (5: 103-104). [Note: Likely referencing Nicolaus or Onkelos/Anqilaus].
4. Al-Qifti mentioned him in (172) saying: 'Valens the Egyptian, and perhaps called Valens the Roman, was a virtuous sage in ancient times in mathematical sciences and astrology judgments. He has beautiful compositions containing majestic purposes of this type. He is the author of the famous book among the people of this craft, called the Roman Bridge.'
5. In the original: 'Experiment'.
6. The known form in this source is: Ra'n and Ru'una.

publisher: Mustafa al-Babi al-Halabi and Sons Library and Printing Company in Egypt
text:
and they have by nature power over it, subtlety in it, and guidance to it, due to what is in their morals of flattery and politics (1) in which they exceeded everyone before and after, and were singled out for excess in it to the exclusion of all nations, until their affair in that became famous, and proverbs were coined about them. Regarding their malice and cunning, Abu Nuwas (2) says:
*I gave you pure advice, O people of Egypt... So take a share from an advisor* (3)
*The Commander of the Faithful cast at you a snake... eater of the snakes of the land, drinker*
*[Do not leap the leap of the foolish and ride... upon the edge of] the sanctuary of the back, unridden* (4)
*If a remnant of Pharaoh's lie is in you... then the Staff of Moses is in the hand of Khasib*
As for the state of those attributed to science among them, I mention what I stood upon and revealed by testing. I was, in my first sitting there, intensely concerned with the books of Galen and Hippocrates, researching their problems, examining their obscurities. I strove every striving and exerted every effort to find among the people of this craft one from whom I could benefit, increase by his discussion, and spark my mind by his negotiation. I found nothing but people upon whose hearts Allah has set a seal, blinded their sights, obliterated their understandings, and placed a barrier between Wisdom and them. They were, with me, as the poet said:
*A people, if you sit with them... minds rust by their proximity*
*They do not make me understand their speech... and what I say is too fine for them*
*They are many to me just as... I am few in their gathering*
foot_note:
1. In Al-Khitat (1: 49): 'Flattery and ugliness'.
2. The four verses are in his Diwan (103-104) praising Al-Khasib, Emir of Egypt.
3. In the Diwan: 'I granted you, O people of Egypt'.
4. Completion from the Diwan (103), its place is blank in the original. Hami al-Zahr (Protector of the Back): is the camel whose back was protected so it is left alone, not used for anything nor prevented from water or pasture. In the original: 'Mani al-Zahr', corrected from the Diwan. The verse did not appear in Al-Khitat.

publisher: Mustafa al-Babi al-Halabi and Sons Library and Printing Company in Egypt
text:
They have adopted characters of abundant disagreement, little fairness, and adhered to slander, obstinacy, rioting, and arrogance. (Due to) their ignorance of the craft of books and their lack of its tools, their lack of its equipment and instruments, their neglect of its conditions, their overlooking of its requirements, the shortness of their minds from grasping its subtleties, and the distance of their intellects from imagining its realities. They did not know that the doctor needs things to aid him in his craft, open its locks for him, clarify its problems, explain its ambiguities, show him its obscurities, give him a taste of the coolness of certainty (1), and clear the darkness of doubts and conjectures from the eye of his insight. These are the Natural Sciences that teach him its principles and beginnings, give him its elements and components (2), and the Syllogistic Laws that guide his mind towards correctness in what he seeks to know and understand, teaching him how to refer (3) its requirements to it, build his measurements upon it, how to proceed from its obvious to its hidden, infer its absent from its apparent, secure against error and the occurrence of nonsense and defect, and verify causes and reasons.
One who wants to be a complete doctor and a virtuous sage must look into Mathematical Sciences, especially Astronomical and Musical ones. The most deserving of people to be of this quality are the doctors of the Brilliant Follower King, who only uses the doctor and astrologer for the sake of support, not for the sake of need and necessity. How so, when his view is the highest, his arrow the winning one, his share the lion's share, and his reach the furthest? One who is like him - and there is no like to him in hitting the joints and hitting the mark - is worthy to choose and not be chosen, and to be independent and not seek aid.
foot_note:
1. In the original: 'coolness of the soul', corrected as established.
2. Al-Ustuquss (Element), also said Ustaquss, is the simple thing from which a compound is composed, like stones, bricks, and trunks from which a palace is composed, and like letters from which speech is composed, and like the one from which number is composed. The four elements are Fire, Air, Water, and Earth. See Mafatih al-Ulum by Al-Khwarizmi (82).
3. In the original: 'yuhallil' (analyze).

publisher: Mustafa al-Babi al-Halabi and Sons Library and Printing Company in Egypt
text:
*Far be it that Time brings his like... Indeed Time is stingy with his like*
When they [did not] task themselves with mastery of what was previously listed, but rather found it long, considered the goal distant, and saw that their purpose from the craft of medicine - which according to them and their opinion is earning - is achieved by what is closer to reach than what the ancients stipulated, and easier to desire, they did not memorize (1) anything but names of a few drugs they dispense in treating every disease without employing their thought in the reality of its type, cause, requirement, and necessity.
Galen criticized, among the three sects of medicine, the Methodist sect (2), for removing all requirements of the medical craft, and restricting treatment to looking at the disease: is it of the type of evacuation so it is countered by retention, or of the type of retention so it is countered by evacuation, without examining the matter of temperament, age, nature, country, habit, and essence.
What do you think of Galen if he witnessed these people who do not stick to a creed, nor attribute themselves to a sect? If a patient is cured at their hands, his cure is by way of coincidence, and if he perishes, it is by necessity and desert. They are as the poet said about their likes:
*And an experienced doctor who has no mind... succeeded in everything he tries by habit*
*He passed one day by a sick man so we said... Cool your eye (be happy), you have been granted martyrdom*
And as another said about some of our sages famous among the commoners for skill and precedence:
*Say to the plague: You and Ibn Zuhr... have exceeded the limit and the end*
*Be gentle with creation a little... one of you is enough*
Or as some contemporary said about them:
*And a juggler doctor... mixes medicine with incantations*
foot_note:
1. In the original: 'So they did not memorize'.
2. In the original: 'The Mountain Sects' (Al-Firaq Al-Jabaliyya), likely a corruption of 'Al-Hilah' (Methodist) or referring to empiricists.

publisher: Mustafa al-Babi al-Halabi and Sons Library and Printing Company in Egypt
text:
*We never saw him treat... a patient and succeed*
*Rather lack of health in... body and heart and survival*
*Possessor of attributes that leave the... body from what it met*
*Lacking movement and... sense and lightness and purity* (1)
*He watered him death with it... and did not know what he watered*
And another said:
*Pulse never crossed his mind... a day nor does he know what is the water (urine)* (2)
*Rather he thought medicine is a Durra'ah (robe)... and a beard white like cotton* (3) [*]
***
Among the amusing things I heard is that there was recently in Egypt a man attached to the Maristan (Hospital) who was summoned to patients just as doctors are summoned. He would enter upon the patient and tell him funny stories and amusing myths, and make funny faces for him. He was, with that, gentle in his humor, expert in it, and capable of it. If the patient's chest expanded and his strength returned, he left him and departed. If he needed to return to the patient, he visited him until he recovered, or whatever Allah willed happened.
Would that the doctors of this age of ours were all capable of such treatment which has no harm and no disaster; rather, its matter is easy on the sick, and its benefit is apparent and clear. How not, when it enlivens the soul, spreads the instinctive heat, strengthens natural powers, and strengthens the body to repel bad harmful humors and wastes, while preserving the principles.
Most of its prominent (4) doctors are Christians and Jews. Regarding that, some of them said:
foot_note:
1. The place of this word is blank in the original.
2. Meaning testing the patient's water, i.e., urine.
3. Durra'ah: A jubbah slit in the front.
4. In the original: 'Al-Muzabarqin' (The decorated/fake). [*] (Shamela Comment): The two verses were narrated by Al-Imad in Al-Kharidah 2:120 attributed to Al-Ayni Al-Masri, then he said: 'I found these two verses in Abu al-Salt's epistle attributed to Zafir al-Haddad.' [Noted in the Addendum]

publisher: Mustafa al-Babi al-Halabi and Sons Library and Printing Company in Egypt
text:
*I say to Muslims all... do you seek fame in our medicine* (1)
*Far from it! You attempted an impossibility... be then Jews or Christians* (2)
The most similar of those I saw among them whom I include in the count of doctors is a Jewish man called Abu al-Khayr Salamah bin Rahmun. He met Abu al-Wafa (3) Al-Mubashir bin Fatik (4), and took from him something of the craft of Logic by which he specialized and distinguished himself from his peers. He caught up with Abu Kathir bin Al-Zaffan (5), the student of Abu al-Hasan Ali bin Ridwan (6), and read some of Galen's books to him. Then he set himself up to teach all books of Logic, and all books of Natural and Divine Philosophy. He explained, interpreted, and summarized according to his claim, but he was not all that (7) in his attainment and verification, and his investigation of the subtle and precise knowledge. Rather, he multiplied (8) his speech and erred, and hastened his answer and slipped.
I asked him in my first meeting and gathering with him about issues with which I opened his discussion (9), which can be understood by one whose span in knowledge has not yet extended, and whose depth and breadth have not increased. He answered them with what revealed his shortcoming, spoke of his inability, and expressed his poor
foot_note:
1. In the original: 'tibbiha' (its medicine).
2. The following text was quoted by Al-Qifti in Ikhbar al-Ulama (142-143), and also Ibn Abi Usaibia (2: 106).
3. After this begins the fragment preserved in Dar al-Kutub No. 354 History of the Egyptian Epistle, and I will refer to it in comments with the symbol 'Q'.
4. Al-Qifti wrote his biography (176-177) and said: 'This man is originally from Damascus and his home is Egypt. He is one of the exemplary sages in the science of the ancients... He had a daughter who lived long after him and narrated Prophetic traditions in Alexandria. He was at the end of the fifth century AH.'
5. In Al-Qifti: 'Al-Kathir Al-Barqani', corruption. Abu Kathir is a kunya and his name is Ephraim bin Al-Zaffan. Ibn Abi Usaibia said in (2: 105): 'Of Israelite religion, and he is one of the famous doctors in the lands of Egypt.' Al-Afdal bin Amir al-Juyush bought ten thousand volumes of his books from him, which some Iraqis had bargained for.
6. See his biography in Ibn Abi Usaibia (2: 99).
7. Q and Ibn Abi Usaibia: 'wa lam yakun hunaka' (he was not there/not up to par). In Al-Qifti: 'wa lam yakun hunalik'.
8. In the original: 'tarahu yukthir' (you see him multiply), I established what is in other sources.
9. In the original: 'istaqbahtu mabahithahu biha' (I found his discussions of them ugly), corrected in other sources.

publisher: Mustafa al-Babi al-Halabi and Sons Library and Printing Company in Egypt
text:
conceptualization and understanding. His likeness in the greatness of his claims and his falling short of the easiest of what he undertakes (1) is like the poet's saying:
*He tucks up his leg for the deep sea... while the wave submerges him on the shore*
Or as another said:
*You wished for two hundred knights... but one knight turned you back* (2)
There was (3) in Egypt a doctor from Antioch named "Georges", nicknamed the Philosopher, in the manner of what is said about the crow: Father of White, and about the stung: Salim (safe). He devoted himself to teasing [Abu al-Khayr Salamah bin Rahmun the Jewish Egyptian doctor (4)] and disparaging him. He used to forge medical and philosophical chapters, presenting them in the guise of the people's expressions, while they were absurd with no meaning, and empty with no benefit. Then he would send them (5) to him asking about their meanings, and seeking clarification of their purposes. So he would speak on them and explain them according to his claim without vigilance (6) or (7) reservation; rather, with looseness and haste, lack of concern and poor attention. So there would be taken from him (8) what causes laughter and expands the chest.
[I was recited (9)] by this Georges about him, and it is among the best I heard in satirizing an ominous (10) doctor, and I suspect him of it:
foot_note:
1. In the original: 'nashr ma huwa muta'atihi', corrected in other sources.
2. Here ends Al-Qifti's quotation in 142-143. See Al-Bayan (1: 249).
3. The following text was quoted by Al-Qifti in 109 and Ibn Abi Usaibia in (2: 106-107).
4. Completion from Al-Qifti, and instead in Ibn Abi Usaibia: 'Ibn Rahmun'.
5. Q only: 'then he sends with them'.
6. Q only: 'Tayaqqun' (certainty).
7. From Al-Qifti and Ibn Abi Usaibia.
8. Al-Qifti and Ibn Abi Usaibia: 'so there is found in it from him'.
9. From Q, Al-Qifti, and Ibn Abi Usaibia.
10. The word 'ominous' and what follows is missing from Q. In the original copy: 'And among the best said in dispraising the ignorant doctor'.

publisher: Mustafa al-Babi al-Halabi and Sons Library and Printing Company in Egypt
text:
*Indeed Abu al-Khayr despite his ignorance... the virtuous is light in his scale*
*His poor patient because of his bad omen... is in a sea of destruction having no shore*
*Three enter in one batch... his face, the coffin, and the washer*
And by some of them:
*Abu al-Khayr in treat... ment has a hand that falls not short*
*Everyone who seeks his medicine... after two days is buried*
*And that which was absent from you... and we witnessed is more* (1)
And among what was said about him:
*The madness of Abu al-Khayr is madness itself... and every madness is to him the height of reason*
*Take him and shackle him and tighten his bond... for he is not sane who underestimates a deranged person*
*He used to harm people with words alone... now he has become harming people with words and deeds* [*]
***
As for the astrologers now in Egypt, they and their doctors are as the lace is cut from the leather, rather as the shoe is sized by the shoe (identical). The best of them does not relate to the science of stars by more than a horoscope (Zaija) he draws (2) and centers he calculates. As for diving deep and navigating in knowing causes and reasons (3), and first principles,
foot_note:
1. In the original copy: 'wa sami'na bi-wasfihi' (and we heard of his description). I established what is in Q and Ibn Abi Usaibia. Al-Qifti did not narrate these verses.
2. It came in "Mafatih al-Ulum" by Al-Khwarizmi 127: "The Zaija is a square or circular image made for the positions of stars in the sphere to look into for judgment for a birth or otherwise. Its derivation in Persian is from Za'ish, meaning birth, then the word was Arabized and used for birth and otherwise." It came in Steingass dictionary (608): "Zaija - astronomical tables". In the original copy: "Zairaja", I established what is in Q. Zairaja is - as Ibn Khaldun mentioned in the Muqaddimah - a branch of the science of Simia (letter magic), by which answers can be extracted from questions by a connection between words. From the poetic Zairaja, answers can be known by special methods and calculation involving addition, subtraction, and multiplication. There is another similar word, which is Zij, plural Azjaj. The Zij: a mathematical craft with numerical laws by which months, days, and past and future dates can be known, and it is the constitution for what astronomers call the Almanac. 
3. This is what is in Q. In the original copy: 'and knowing causes and reasons' (repetition). [*] (Shamela Comment): This speech appeared in Ikhbar al-Ulama bi-Akhbar al-Hukama by Al-Qifti p. 159. [Noted in the Addendum]

publisher: Mustafa al-Babi al-Halabi and Sons Library and Printing Company in Egypt
text:
there is none among them who ascends to this degree, or rises to this rank, or flies in this atmosphere, or seeks light from this light (1) except Abu al-Hasan Ali bin al-Nadr (2) known as Al-Adib (The Man of Letters), may Allah be pleased with him, from the people of Upper Egypt. He was among the [notable (3)] virtuous ones, counted among the good things of this time (4). We will mention him in what we resume, Allah Almighty willing.
As for the imitating sect whose share of knowledge is husks without kernels (5), appearances without interiors, and bodies without spirits, the best among them now is a man known as Rizq Allah al-Nahhas (6). He has in the branches of this craft some training and experience, and with its experimentations (7) some expertise. He is the greatest of astrologers there and their elder who taught them, and their prince in whom they seek refuge (8). All of them are attributed to him, written in his register, acknowledging his merit, and scooping from his sea (9). He is a man of natural wit who jokes and acts dissolute (10).
Among his amusing stories about himself, he said: An Egyptian woman asked me to look for her into a camel matter (Jmaliyya) concerning her. So I took the altitude of the sun for the time, verified the degree of the ascendant, the twelve houses, and the centers of the planets. I drew all that before me
foot_note:
1. In the original: 'la yuhalliq' and 'la yastadi'', I established what is in Q (without 'la' - negation).
2. In the original: 'Ibn al-Nasr' with un-dotted Sad. I established what is in Q.
3. From Q.
4. Q: 'min hasanat al-zaman'.
5. In Al-Lisan: 'Lubb of walnut and almond etc.: what is in its cavity, plural Lubub'. Q: 'Al-Lubab'. What I established from the original is more fitting.
6. In the original: 'Bin al-Nahhas', corrected in Q and Al-Qifti 127.
7. In the original: 'and with its particulars', I established what is in Q. In Al-Qifti: 'and with its experiments'.
8. Q: 'who praised them and presented them'. In Al-Qifti: 'and their elder who taught them magic' only.
9. In the original: 'and from his knowledge', I established what is in Q.
10. Yatakhal'a: Shows Khala'a (dissoluteness/shamelessness). In the original: 'Yatakhalaq', corrected in Q.

publisher: Mustafa al-Babi al-Halabi and Sons Library and Printing Company in Egypt
text:
on the calculation board (1), and began speaking about each house of them as usual, while I was during that sensing her matter (2) and she was silent not uttering a word. I was baffled by that and a great languor overtook me, and she had thrown a dirham to me (3). He said: So I resumed speaking and said: I see upon you a loss in the house of your wealth (4), so preserve and beware! She said: Now you have hit the mark and spoken the truth. By God, it was as you mentioned. I said: And did you lose anything? She said: Yes, the dirham I threw to you! And she left me and departed.
Egyptians are the people who use astrology judgments most, believe in them, rely on them, are fond of them, and rest in them. It has reached such an extent in their affair that not one of them makes a movement of the partial movements whose arts cannot be counted nor its parts and directions obtained, nor its directions controlled, nor its ends restricted (5), nor its types numbered except in horoscopes they choose, [and configurations they rely upon (6)].
I witnessed one day a man from the stokers in the bathhouse furnace (7) asking the mentioned Rizq Allah about a praiseworthy hour to cut his nails. I marveled at the height of his ambition despite the lowness of his status (8) and the baseness of his profession.
Among the amazing stories regarding their excessive use of astrology judgments and care for them,
foot_note:
1. This is in Q, in the original: 'in the board'.
2. Q: 'sensing for her'.
3. Al-Qifti: 'and she had thrown a dirham to me'.
4. This is in Q and Al-Qifti, in the original: 'loss of the house of your wealth'.
5. Q: 'nor its styles estimated'.
6. From Q.
7. Q: 'furnace of a bathhouse'.
8. Q: 'with the lowness of his status'.

publisher: Mustafa al-Babi al-Halabi and Sons Library and Printing Company in Egypt
text:
is what I witnessed in Upper Egypt. A governor imprisoned a man from [some of (1)] the people of that area who used to look into the science of stars. Someone dear to him interceded (2) for him, so he accepted the intercession and ordered his release. He was in the prison in constant torment and exhausting fatigue. When they came to him and said: Go to your affair (3), he took out an astrolabe from his sleeve and looked into it, then took the ascendant of the time and looked into it. He found it blameworthy, so he asked them to leave him in his place (4) until a time agreed upon suitable for leaving the prison. They returned to the governor and told him his news (5). He laughed at him and marveled at his ignorance and corruption of his mind, and granted his request, left him in his state, and prolonged the duration of his detention.
In what I cited of the news of doctors and astrologers now in Egypt is sufficiency and communication, until I stand for it a second standing, and say in it a healing saying.
Now, I mention conditionally those whom I met of its men of letters and wits, and its virtuous ones in literature and its scholars.
The most deserving of precedence, and most worthy of the fullest share of glorification is "Judge Abu al-Hasan Ali Ibn al-Nadr (6)" known as Al-Adib. Possessor of abundant literature, vast knowledge, and brilliant virtue. He has in all parts of Wisdom the long hand (mastery) and the first rank.
He had come to Fustat seeking from its Vizier nicknamed Al-Afdal employment and service, but his hope was disappointed in him,
foot_note:
1. From Q.
2. Q: 'so he interceded'.
3. Q: 'to your path'.
4. In the original: 'to be patient with him', I established what is in Q.
5. In the original: 'his news', I established what is in Q (telling him his news).
6. In the original: 'Al-Nasr' with un-dotted Sad, corruption corrected in Q and Al-Kharidah (2: 195) from Dar al-Kutub manuscript No (10098 Z) and Al-Tali' al-Sa'id by Al-Adfuwi. Where he mentioned he was one of the workers of the Egyptian lands in the time of Al-Afdal Shahanshah.

publisher: Mustafa al-Babi al-Halabi and Sons Library and Printing Company in Egypt
text:
his hope was lost, and his endeavor failed. So he said from a poem in which he blames Time, and complains of disappointment and deprivation:
*Between pride and humiliation is a path... whose lighthouse is apparent to the eye of every successful one*
*So walk it in all places and avoid... the arrogance of the proud and the humiliation of the flatterer*
*I have brought of merchandise the best... to the most majestic chosen one and most generous pious one* (1)
*And I hoped for ease of life under his canopy... inevitably whether I sold (my wares) or did not sell* (2)
*A thought resembling certainty and I did not imagine... that Time, with what it watered me, would make me choke*
*And to my blamer for greed is a clear saying... if you had seen a cloud you would not have slept* (3)
*I did not seek except the best seeking and I did not... connect hope with a rope other than the most trustworthy* (4)
*And if Destiny refuses provision to a man... the trick of the seeker of provision does not avail him*
*By the life of the hostility of calamities, even if it threw... my gathering with an arrow, it scattered and dispersed* (5)
*I will fight Time defending my chivalry... and I am forbidden the glory of victory if I am not truthful* (6)
And he has regarding this trip of his (7), when his despair of reaching his hope and attaining his desire became strong, and he resolved to return (8) from Fustat to his residence, urging asceticism, encouraging contentment,
foot_note:
1. In the original: 'I have brought of merchandise the bulk... from every chosen one and most generous of what is selected' [I established what is in Q, Al-Kharidah and Al-Tali' al-Sa'id. However, the last word in Al-Tali' al-Sa'id is: 'Muwathaq'.
2. Q: 'And I found'. The word 'Riwaqihi' (canopy) is in the original: 'Zilalihi' (shadows), I established what is in Q and Al-Kharidah. In Al-Tali' al-Sa'id: 'under his robe', corruption.
3. In the original: 'wa li-'a'ini' corrected in Q. In Al-Kharidah: 'wa li-'atibi'.
4. Q: 'Bi-ghayr habl al-awthaq', in Al-Kharidah: 'Bi-habl ghayr muwathaq'.
