5. In the original: 'ramat hazzi' (threw my luck), corrected in Q and Al-Kharidah.
6. In the original: 'la-asiranna al-ya's' (I will become despair), corrected in Q and Al-Kharidah.
7. In the original: 'And he has from a poem other than this', I established what is in Q and Al-Kharidah.
8. Q: 'Al-Sudur', both are correct.

publisher: Mustafa al-Babi al-Halabi and Sons Library and Printing Company in Egypt
text:
condemning humbleness, and regretting the humiliation of his cheek and the spilling of his face's water (dignity):
*My sorrow for a kingdom of contentment, had I... enjoyed in it his possession, the possessor*
*And for a treasure of despair I had acquired... if calamities had not wreaked havoc in it and destroyed*
*I swore to make the water of my face after it... like blood spilled by pilgrims at a rite*
*And a brother of beautiful patience whom I cut off... in obedience to the hope that was not attained*
*O may Allah fight Necessity as a state... which path has it not taken the youth through* (1)
*How often I spent the night complained to [it stripped... my rings knocking] with the palm of a restrainer* (2)
*And a mouth on a foot it threw, and eyes... whose sockets were kohl-ed with the tread of a hoof* (3)
*And clothed in patience and piety, she called... so he turned away from her in the exhibition of the ascetic* (4)
*She kept turning him like the turning of the stick... the head of the camel to a kneeling place from a kneeling place*
And he has to a chief whom he used to task with visiting him but he sat back from that out of grandeur and arrogance:
*Did you consider yourself too great to walk a coincidence... and you imposed it on me, you have tasked me with excess* (5)
*Do not lie, for we would not have obliged a... right while you see it has dropped from you*
*If I sold you the soul a sale you would own it... by, justice would be a stipulated condition upon you* (6)
*So is there a way that you do not contact me... and do not task the likes of me with these plans* (7)
*Perhaps the page of what is between me and you might... be folded and not include other than what has passed* (8)
foot_note:
1. This is in Q and Al-Kharidah, in the original: 'O may Allah fight Necessity, for it... walked paths with the youth he did not walk'.
2. In the original: 'lam ya'ti' (did not come), the correction of the verse and its completion from Q and Al-Kharidah.
3. This verse is missing from the original.
4. In the original: 'clothed in victory', corrected in Q and Al-Kharidah.
5. In the original and Al-Kharidah: 'Musarafatan' (exchanging) with Ra', I established what is in Q (Musadafatan - coincidence/meeting).
6. Q and Al-Kharidah: 'by it upon me, justice would be'.
7. In the original: 'and do not task the likes of me with roads and plans', corrected in Q and Al-Kharidah.
8. In the original: 'and what has passed of our affair', corrected in Q and Al-Kharidah.

publisher: Mustafa al-Babi al-Halabi and Sons Library and Printing Company in Egypt
text:
And he (1) has in the opening of a letter:
*Your letter came out of anger so it comforted me... with what it contained of the comfort of the eye with sleep* (2)
*I read it so its meanings flowed in every limb... of mine as water flows in the branch* (3)
*I do not say you sent the soul in it to... my heart, but you sent the soul into my body*
And he has regarding the severity of his affliction:
*O Answerer of the prayer of the one seeking refuge in Him... and O Reliever of the night of dark distress*
*The doors have been locked against us and prevented... and Your door is above prevention and locking*
*We fear Your justice that the decree runs by it... and we hope in You, so be for the fearful, the Hope* (4)
Among its famous poets is Abu al-Tahir bin Ismail bin Muhammad known as Ibn Miknasa (5). He is a poet of much versatility, little affectation, mastering the embroidery (6) of serious poetry and humorous, and having a share in its delicate and robust styles. In the prime of his youth and the beginning of his novelty, he loved a boy from the sons of the Egyptian military called Izz al-Dawla Fa'iq. He is now in Egypt one of the counted men of its state and its prominent elders. He remained residing on his love for him and infatuation with him until hair erased his beauties and time changed his features. This Mu'izz al-Dawla (7) remained committed to him, benevolent to him, encompassing him, until Time separated them.
He was in the days of the Commander of the Armies Badr al-Jamali attached to an official of the Christians known as Abu Malih,
foot_note:
1. After this word in the original is a blank space of about two pages from the original. I was able to fill this gap from Q and Al-Kharidah. The common part between Q and Al-Kharidah ends at the word 'Al-Raji' (the Hope), the conclusion of the following Jim-rhymed verses, then 'Q' is unique in completing the deficiency which I will note the end of.
2. In Al-Kharidah: 'fa-ab'asani' (so it made me miserable), corruption corrected in Q and Al-Tali' al-Sa'id. Its opening in Al-Tali' al-Sa'id (222): 'Wafa kitabuka' (Your letter arrived).
3. In Al-Tali' al-Sa'id: 'Nafakhta al-ruh' (You breathed the soul).
4. Here ends the common part of the completion between Q and Al-Kharidah, then 'Q' continues alone.
5. Ibn Shakir wrote his biography in Al-Fawat (1: 26) and said: 'He died around the year five hundred.'
6. In the original: 'Wa'y' (consciousness).
7. Previously mentioned as 'Izz al-Dawla Fa'iq' and thus they appeared in the original.

publisher: Mustafa al-Babi al-Halabi and Sons Library and Printing Company in Egypt
text:
and most of his poems were about him. When the command transferred to Al-Afdal, he attempted to praise him, but he did not accept him nor turn to him. The reason for his deprivation was what preceded for Abu Malih and his elegies for him when dead, especially his saying:
*The sky of hono... rs was folded and the sun of praise was wrapped up*
*He was not of the weak, vile... of men nor the stingy*
*The Christians disbelieved after they... tied the religion of the Messiah to him*
Izz al-Dawla bin Fa'iq sponsored him and took care of his condition until he died.
Al-Afdal did not turn to any of the poets as he turned to a man from the people of Ma'arrat al-Nu'man (1) called Abu al-Hasan Ali bin Ja'far bin al-Nun (2). He poured upon him the clouds of his beneficence, and made flow for him the milk of his favor, titled him Amin [Al-Mulk (3)], brought him close, and singled him out. His poetry was not there (up to par) (4), rather it was affected and arbitrary. I do not know anyone from the people of those lands who narrates a single verse or more of his, due to the aversion of natures to his speech and the repulsion of ears from his method.
Al-Afdal ordered him one day to describe a gathering in which fruits and basils were arranged. So he said from his Muzdawijah (couplet poem) (5) describing the fingered citron (Utrujj Musabba'):
*As if its fingered citron... is hands of criminals cut from wrists*
He erred and did not realize, and behaved badly and did not feel; because he intended to praise the citron but made the King's soul disgusted by it and turned it away from it. Had he intended to disparage it, he would not have added to what he described of hands cut from their wrists. The skillful eloquent one is he who, if he describes something, gives it its due, fulfills its condition, and describes it with what
foot_note:
1. Here ends the omission I noted at the beginning of the previous page.
2. Q: 'Al-Nuwayn'.
3. From Q.
4. In the original: 'hunaka bi-l-jayyid' (there in good quality), corrected in Q, and the word 'bi-l-jayyid' is inserted.
5. In the original: 'Muzdawijat', corrected in Q.

publisher: Mustafa al-Babi al-Halabi and Sons Library and Printing Company in Egypt
text:
suits it in both states of praise and blame, and puts everything in its place in his prose and verse (1). Where is this poet in his etiquette, skill in the craft (2), and intelligence, compared to Abu Ali al-Hasan Ibn Rashiq, when Al-Muizz bin Badis ordered him to describe a [fingered (3)] citron that was before him (4), so he said improvising on the spot:
*A citron with smooth tips, soft... meeting the eyes with beauty not diminished (5)*
*As if it spread a palm to its Creator... praying for long life for Ibn Badis*
If Ibn al-Rumi intended to praise the rose by his saying:
*O praiser of the rose, his mistake never ceases (6)... did you not contemplate it in the palm of its picker*
*Like the anus of a mule when he exposes it... during defecation while the rest of the dung is in its center*
He would have been mistaken, ignorant, or heedless. But he said that when he intended to blame it and wanted to demean it. Look at this comparison, the likes of which in wonder has not been heard. So may Allah curse his devil (7)!
Likewise Abdullah bin al-Mu'tazz in his saying describing the moon in verses:
*It spent the night as it pleased its enviers... when it sought nearness to sleep it deviated (8)*
*The larvae of mosquitoes provoke it... in a moon like the back of a rat (9)*
And the saying of Ibn al-Mu'tazz about the moon in verses:
*O thief of lights from the morning sun... O bereaver of my good sleep and my disturber*
foot_note:
1. Q: 'of his prose and verse'.
2. Q: 'and his knowledge of the craft'.
3. From Q.
4. In the original: 'in his hand', I established what is in Q.
5. Mabkhus: Diminished. In the original 'Manhus' (ominous), corrected in Q.
6. This is in Q. In the original: 'min ghalat'.
7. This is in Q. In the original: 'May Allah curse that'.
8. In Diwan Ibn al-Mu'tazz (2: 116): 'As it pleased its enemies'.
9. In the original: 'fa-min qamar', corrected from the Diwan.

publisher: Mustafa al-Babi al-Halabi and Sons Library and Printing Company in Egypt
text:
*As for the sun's light in you, it is decreasing... and I see the heat of its fire has not decreased*
*The comparison in you did not succeed with anything useful... peeling off vitiligo like the skin of a leper* (1)
This is a chapter that if we investigated thoroughly would lengthen and widen (2), so let us leave it and connect of our rope what was cut (3).
Ismail bin Miknasa (4) said in a poem:
*O blamer, winds of blame did not blow... on the fire of my passion except it increased in burning*
*So leave me to an eye that if its water dries... sees it a right of love to shed blood*
*How many tears gave their rein to my passion... in the evening when they drove the bridled riding camels*
*And an eye protected by the memory of days spent in Al-Hima... from sleep visiting it*
*And by God, a heart whose worries struck it... so no edge remained of it except it was notched* (5)
And he has from another:
*The knots of his waist became thin as if they... were derived from his promise and my endurance* (6)
*And his temples curled as if they... were stolen from his curly character* (7)
[And from it (8)]:
foot_note:
1. In the Diwan: 'minka bi-ta'il' (from you with anything useful). In the original: 'bi-maslakh', corrected in Q. In the Diwan: 'Muslakh'.
2. This is in Q. In the original: 'If I investigated it, it would widen'.
3. This is in Q. In the original: 'of our purpose what was cut'.
4. Q: 'Abu al-Tahir bin Miknasa', both are correct.
5. In the original: 'mithlama', I established what is in Q and Al-Kharidah (2: 301).
6. In the original: 'min qaddihi' (from his stature), corrected in Q. In Al-Kharidah (2: 299) 'min tihihi' (from his pride), which is not correct.
7. In the original: 'min sha'rihi' (from his hair), I established what is in Q and Al-Kharidah.
8. From Q.

publisher: Mustafa al-Babi al-Halabi and Sons Library and Printing Company in Egypt
text:
*Why does he act harshly while people claimed... that dew (generosity) is specific to the moist (generous) face* (1)
*Do not let a reddened cheek deceive you... that became thin, for in the ruby is the nature of the rock*
And he has from a poem:
*And a soldier always wherever... you meet him meets you with all weapons*
*His eyebrow is a bow and his eyelids... are arrows and his sides are the bending of spears*
*[He went and the wine did to him as... the breeze of winds does to the branch (2)*
He raided in this last verse upon Khalid al-Katib in his saying:
*My eye saw two sights in him as it saw... the sun and the illuminating moon on earth* (3)
*In the evening when he greeted me with roses as if... cheeks added some to some* (4)
*[And handed me a cup as if its mixture... was my tears when sleep turned away from my eye (5)]*
*He went and the wine did in his movements... like the action of the breeze of wind in the tender branch*
As for the verse before it (6), poets have circulated it.
Among the pleasant things that occurred in it is the saying of some of the contemporaries:
*I have from the Sons of the Yellow (Romans) a gazelle who threw... at my heart with the arrow of the hitting Houris*
*An arrow of the glance he threw at me... from near, a bow of the eyebrow*
*As if his eye in the bowels... is the sword of Ali bin Abi Talib*
And he has regarding paper gifted to him:
foot_note:
1. The word 'yajfu' (act harshly) is missing from the original. Established from Q and Al-Kharidah.
2. The verse is missing from the original, established from Q and Al-Kharidah (2: 301).
3. In the original: 'Ka-annama huwa al-shams' (as if he is the sun), I established what is in Q and Al-Kharidah.
4. In the original: 'ala ba'd', I established what is in Q.
5. This is from Al-Kharidah only.
6. Meaning his saying: His eyebrow is a bow and his eyelids... are arrows and his sides are the bending of spears.

publisher: Mustafa al-Babi al-Halabi and Sons Library and Printing Company in Egypt
text:
*He gifted us paper thin... ner than the impossible drink in creation*
*The lines tear it... as if it is the honor of the miser*
*Neither colored nor polished... nor wide nor long*
*Except whiteness you thought... leprosy on a skinny body* (1)
Some of the contemporaries exhausted this meaning, saying mentioning a bundle of paper brought out to him from the Sultan's treasury, used in the Diwan of Correspondence. Some writers of the Diwan used to steal paper, but that bundle was safe from him due to its ugliness and low price:
*And paper that resembles our states... in every meaning and mimics them*
*A form was made generic for handwriting in it... nothing in ugliness approaches it* (2)
*Whatever our pens draw in it... penetrates through its page*
*We deposit our hidden secrets in it... and it reveals them to the glances*
*Different parts, rough... the palm touches it and it makes it bleed*
*Like the skin of a leper in its color... describing according to truth and resemblance*
*If it were a character/creation it would be repugnant... or if it were a creation it would be a deformation*
*It stumbles the pens until you see... their sharp edges blunted in it* (3)
*It leaves them, their ends resembling... their tops in lack of sharpening* (4)
*After its sharpener imitated with its tips... the tips of the brown spears of handwriting* (5)
foot_note:
1. This verse is missing from Q.
2. In the original: 'fiha ma yudaniha', corrected from Q.
3. In the original: 'yughayyir al-aqlam' (changes the pens), I established what is in Q.
4. The first word is missing from the original, as is the word 'al-bara' (sharpening) and half the word after it, completion from Q. In Q: 'fi qidam al-bara', and the explanation is what I established from the original. Hawadiha means its beginnings, i.e., heads.
5. The verse appeared in the original truncated, ending with the word 'atraf' (tips), completion from Q.

publisher: Mustafa al-Babi al-Halabi and Sons Library and Printing Company in Egypt
text:
*And the fingertips do in running over it... like lightning ... it* (1)
*And how many have come to steal it striving... who would ransom it with their soul*
*He who sees its layers says... may the hand that packed it be paralyzed*
*The weevil has messed with its middles... and the mouse has gnawed its edges* (2)
*If his bundle were offered you would not find... a buyer among creation to buy it*
*If he offered a penny for it mistakenly... it would be the widest waste and foolishness* (3)
*The thief does not take from it nor... does anyone assassinate it by a trick in it* (4)
*The pebbles are counted fully... before its faults are counted* (5)
*Whoever blamed a possessor of deficiency or baseness... he means it by that blame* (6)
Abu al-Tahir (7) said:
*I said when coquetry curled... the hair on his cheek*
*This is a sign by which... beauty appeared and spread*
*Never before his temple was seen... a scorpion solving (settling in) the moon* (8)
This is a pleasant meaning but he stole it from two verses recited to me in Egypt by a man named Abu Muhammad Al-Takriti, one of Abu Hamid Al-Ghazali's students, attributed to Abu Hamid, and I did not hear them from anyone else:
foot_note:
1. Thus the verse appeared in the original, and it is missing from Q.
2. In the original: 'bi-atrafiha' (its tips), the correction is what I established from Q.
3. Tadyi'an (waste) appeared thus.
4. In the original: 'na'ba laha' corrected in Q. And 'min hilah' is in the original and Q: 'fi hilah'.
5. 'Mustawfiyan 'addahu', its place is blank in the original, establishment from Q.
6. The word 'wa dha khissah' (and possessor of baseness) place is white in the original, establishment from Q.
7. He is Abu al-Tahir Ismail bin Muhammad, known as Ibn Miknasa, his name was noted previously on p. 43.
8. In Al-Kharidah (2: 302): 'Never was seen at all before this'.

publisher: Mustafa al-Babi al-Halabi and Sons Library and Printing Company in Egypt
text:
*The scorpions of his temple settled in his cheek... a moon, so he became too majestic by it for comparison* (1)
*And we have known it (Scorpio) settling in its constellation... so among the wonders is how it settled in it (the moon)*
Abu al-Tahir also said from a poem, when some Emirs resolved upon him to go out (2) with him to Sham to fight the Ghuzz (3), beginning:
*Not disobeying you is the straightening of my stick... so decrease my blame or increase* (4)
*Say to my master when he called me to a matter... in which I stood for him the station of slaves*
*My trick is weak and my utility is little... and my end is near and my new is worn out* (5)
*What do I have to do with Sham when I... see the fire of its war kindled*
*A land whose Jinns are the demons of the Ghuzz... and a land whose beasts are lions* (6)
*And the pits (Jifar) that say whenever... it is said: Are you not full?: Is there any more?* (7)
*And it is as if I see myself on a camel... the last of people in the crowd of crowds* (8)
*Black-faced looking into matters... dilemmas of accidents, black*
foot_note:
1. Thus narrated in Wafiyat al-A'yan, in the biography of Abu Hamid Al-Ghazali. In Al-Kharidah and Q: 'wa yajillu bihi 'an al-tashabbuh'. Ibn Khallikan said: 'And I saw these two verses in another place attributed to someone else.'
2. Q: 'fi al-masir' (in marching).
3. In Al-Lisan and Al-Qamus 'Al-Ghuzz' is a race of Turks. See Ibn Al-Athir (9: 141-147).
4. In the original: 'ghayr 'adin', corrected from Al-Kharidah (2: 308). In Q: 'Aasin' (hard/difficult), it is said 'asa' if it became hard.
5. Al-Ghana', with Fath: Benefit/Utility. In the original: 'ana'i' (my suffering), corrected in Q and Al-Kharidah (2: 308).
6. In the original: 'hannah', corrected in Q and Al-Kharidah. Al-Afariyah with Ya before the end: plural of 'Ifriyah, which is Ifrit. In the original: 'afaribah', and in Q and Al-Kharidah: 'afarituh', their correction is what I established. See Al-Lisan (Afar 263).
7. Al-Jifar: plural of Jufrah with Damma, which is a wide round pit. In the original and Q: 'alladhi yaqul' (which says), corrected in Al-Kharidah. In Al-Kharidah: 'qila imtala'ti hal mazid', and in Q: 'qul hal imtala'ti', and the meter does not fit with either. The correct is what I established.
8. In the original: 'wa ka-anni ala', I established what is in Q and Al-Kharidah.

publisher: Mustafa al-Babi al-Halabi and Sons Library and Printing Company in Egypt
text:
*And if it is said tomorrow the people meet... do not forget, for it is the verse of the poem (the main point)*
*Where no eye of mine sees him sharp... when the glitter of iron appears to him*
*Where my tongue is not feared nor... the rein of the raider turned away from me by my recitation* (1)
*Indeed my opinion when the arrow of an archer... is aimed towards me is other than a sound opinion* (2)
*So if I am killed I would be worthy... of my entering Hellfire and my eternity*
*So forgive me its stumble and remain for glory... and suppression of enemies and rage of the envier* (3)
And he said from a poem in the style of Abu al-Shammaqmaq (4):
*I am the one Abu al-Shammaqmaq... spoke to you about*
*And he said about me that I... was the drinking companion of Al-Muttaqi*
*And I was was was was... of the shooters of the hazelnut*
*Until when will I be found like this... a billy goat with a long neck* (5)
*With a flowing beard... and a shaved mustache* (6)
*[Would that it had been created... from the face of an anal (Halqi) sheikh (7)]*
He said (8) from another:
*I lived fifty, rather increasing... a fool as you see*
foot_note:
1. Q: 'ra's al-ba'ir anni' (head of the camel from me), in Al-Kharidah: 'zimam al-ba'ir' (rein of the camel).
2. Q and Al-Kharidah: 'idha tasaddada nahwi', it is said saddadahu fa-tasaddada.
3. Q and Al-Kharidah: 'wa abqa li-l-hamd' (remain for praise).
4. Q: 'Abu al-Raqa'maq', who is another poet and not intended. As for Abu al-Shammaqmaq, he is Marwan bin Muhammad and was a contemporary of Bashar and Abu Nuwas. His biography is in "Tarikh Baghdad" 7128 and Ibn Khallikan within the biography of Yazid bin Mazyad. He did not have a separate biography. As for Abu al-Raqa'maq, he is Abu Hamid Ahmed bin Muhammad Al-Antaki, Al-Tha'alibi wrote his biography in Al-Yatimah (1: 238) and Ibn Khallikan in Al-Wafiyat (1: 41).
5. Q and Al-Kharidah: 'Hatta mata abqa' (Until when will I remain).
6. In Al-Lisan: 'sabala sabil' (let down/flowing). In Al-Kharidah: 'bi-lihyatin musbalah'.
7. The verse is from Q and Al-Kharidah. Halqi: The passive homosexual, and it came in its original: 'halq' corrupted.
8. In the original: 'wa qawluhu', corrected in Q.

publisher: Mustafa al-Babi al-Halabi and Sons Library and Printing Company in Egypt
text:
*I think the doum fruit (Muql) is hazelnuts... and likewise salt is sugar* (1)
*And I think the tall of... everything is round*
*I have aged aged aged aged... and my mind goes backwards*
*Wonder how everything... I see changing*
*I do not see eggs being... eaten except peeled*
*And if glass is hit with stones... it breaks*
*And if a dead person dies... he does not smell ambergris* (2)
Among the poets of the Egyptians in this time of ours is one who says - he is Abu Musharraf Al-Dajarjawi (3), attributed to Dajarja, which is a village (4) in Upper Egypt:
*A judge who, when two opponents separate, returns them... to dispute with a non-decisive judgment*
*He shows asceticism in the world and its glitter... openly, and secretly accepts a camel's dung*
Among them is one who says, he is Abu al-Hasan Ali bin al-Barqi, from the people of Qus:
*Time threw me with every arrow of its... and surprised me with separation after separation* (5)
*And gathered in my heart every sadness... and separated between my loved ones and me*
*So in my heart is the heat of every heart... and in my eye are the tears of every eye*
And he has from verses:
*I have a slumber, I knew not what is the slumber of sleep... as if my eyelids are my ears and sleep is the censure* (6)
foot_note:
1. Al-Muql: Fruit of the Doum palm. In the original: 'Al-Baql' (herbs), in Q and Al-Kharidah: 'Al-Masl' (whey), the correct is what I established. In the original: 'sukran. wa ahsib al-milh sukran', corrected in Q and Al-Kharidah.
2. The verse is missing from Q and Al-Kharidah. In the original: 'la yasman' (does not get fat), corruption.
3. Yaqut said, when discussing Dajarja: 'A late poet known to Egyptians came out of it called (Abu) Al-Musharraf. He has good poetry.' In the original: 'Al-Dajarjaray' corrected in Q and Al-Kharidah.
4. In the original: 'to his village Dajarjara which is', corrected in Q.
5. In Q the beginning of this verse was combined with the end of the next one becoming one verse. Thus it came in Al-Tali' al-Sa'id by Al-Adfuwi 219.
6. In the original: 'wa bayna jafwati', corrected in Q, Al-Kharidah and Al-Tali' al-Sa'id. The last word of the verse is missing from the original and established from the three copies.

publisher: Mustafa al-Babi al-Halabi and Sons Library and Printing Company in Egypt
text:
Among them is one who says, he is Abu Muhammad Abdullah bin al-Tabbakh the Scribe, satirizing a short-necked man (Awqas). I recited them to Abu al-Hasan [Ali bin (1)] Al-Sufi Al-Hanbali (2):
*His neck veins shortened and his occiput sank... as if he expects to be slapped* (3)
*As if he had tasted the first strike... and sensed a second one so he gathered himself*
Among them is one who says, he is Abu Abdullah Muhammad bin Muslim the Scribe:
*The camel-driver forced her through the wilderness and she abandoned... and the fifth (day of thirst) passed over her followed by the tenth* (4)
*The heat of midday made her lean as if it... is passion, and it is a heart harmed by abandonment*
Among them is one who says, and I do not verify his name, regarding a man nicknamed Al-Rashid (5):
*What a difference between Al-Rashi... d and Harun Al-Rashid*
*This one chastises with ski... ns (whips) and that one strengthens with soldiers* (6)
Among them is one who says, he is Mahmoud bin Nasir Al-Iskandari (7), scribe of Judge Ibn Hadid, regarding a harelip doctor with deformed creation:
*Our friend the doctor is a rarity... the eyes of people have taken from him* (8)
*Fangs of a ghoul and lip of a camel... and head of a mule and chin of a Nisnas (monkey)*
Among them is one who says, he is Abu Nasr Zafir bin Qasim known as Al-Haddad (9) from the people of Alexandria, and he wrote to me with it in a letter:
foot_note:
1. From Q.
2. Q: 'Al-Jabali'.
3. In the original: 'wa ghaba qadhaluhu' (and his occiput disappeared), I established what is in Q.
4. In the original: 'ta'ashshaqaha' (fell in love with her), corrected in Q.
5. In the original: 'named Harun Al-Rashid', I established what is in Q.
6. Ta'zir: Beating for discipline less than the Hadd punishment. This is the correct placement of the verse as in the original. It came reversed in Q which is incorrect: 'This one strengthens with soldiers... and that one chastises with skins'.
7. Q: 'Al-Iskandarani'.
8. In the original: 'have taken it from the eyes of people', corrected in Q and Al-Kharidah.
9. Ibn Khallikan wrote his biography in "Wafiyat al-A'yan", and Yaqut in "Irshad al-Arib" and mentioned he died in 529.

publisher: Mustafa al-Babi al-Halabi and Sons Library and Printing Company in Egypt
text:
*And no bird whose wing Time clipped... so it deprived it of a nest and lost it a mate*
*Remembering fluff among the branches of a thicket... hidden wings that do not fly due to weakness*
*When it wraps itself in darkness it confides its worries... to the modulation of a melody almost hidden from thinness* (1)
*Is more longing than me when distance obeyed regarding you... air and water racing the glance*
*It turned away having from you what if I measure it... with what it is in, it would be fuller in merit* (2)
He also said:
*They departed, and were it not that I... hope for meeting I would have died* (3)
*By God I did not part from you... but I parted from my heart* (4)
Among them is one who says, he is Abu al-Qasim bin Rushd (5) Al-Masri:
*How many say to me travel to... the lands of Iraq, you will fall into Rakha' (prosperity)* (6)
*By my life they told the truth, I have fallen... into the middle of Rakha' with the Kha' brought forward (Khara' - filth)*
Among them is one who says - he is Al-Naji Al-Masri - satirizing a bathhouse:
*Indeed our bathhouse which we are in... is in need of a bath*
*We entered it while we were children of Sam (Shem)... and exited while we were children of Ham*
Some contemporaries said in this meaning:
*Our bathhouse is in more dire need... than he who settles in it for a bath*
*Colors of people whiten in others... but this one lends them clothes of soot*
*I was from Sam so when I entered it... for the misery of my luck it turned me from Ham* (7)
Among them is one who says, he is Abu al-Hasan Marwan bin Uthman:
*Sickness has enabled itself of me until as if I am... an imagined meaning in a hidden question*
foot_note:
1. Q: 'min diqqah' (from fineness).
2. Q: 'kan fi wasfihi wa fi'.
3. Q: 'arju al-iyab qadaytu nahbi' (hope for return I would have died).
4. Q: 'By God I did not part from them'.
5. In the original: 'Bin Zubayd', I established what is in Q.
6. Q: 'Al-Rakha' shortened, and likewise 'Kha' shortened in the next verse.
7. In the original: 'dakhaltuha' (I entered her), corrected in Q and Al-Kharidah (2: 305).

publisher: Mustafa al-Babi al-Halabi and Sons Library and Printing Company in Egypt
text:
*[And if his eyes permitted my eyes in sleep... my imagination would be more obscure than the phantom of imagination (1)]*
*I was generous with my soul while it is dear to me... and generous with my heart while it is precious to me*
*And I feared that my death would be decreed upon me... and I would not fulfill my desires with a day of union* (2)
*And the easiest of what I encounter of passion is that it is... avoidance of coquetry not avoidance of boredom*
*If that avoidance from him was boredom... I would have tightened the mounts of my saddles away from the world* (3)
This is from the saying of Abbas bin al-Ahnaf:
*If you were blaming, my anguish would calm... I would hope for your satisfaction and visit without (4) [watcher*
*But you turned away so I had no trick... the turning away of the bored is different from the turning away of the blaming]*
And by Marwan:
*What is the matter with your heart submitting... is there passion in it or madness* (5)
*The hidden was revealed by what you hide, so certainty removed doubt*
*Until when between the ribs and sides is a buried love*
*And until when is the heart of the enthralled a hostage in the hand of calamity*
*O procrastinator of my heart's debts... it is time that debts be paid*
*Eyes stared at him regarding you... and thoughts were divided regarding you*
*And you stole the minds of people... with glances containing temptation*
*And a stature of garden branches... and where do branches reach you*
*Beauty in branches is... an art and in this it is arts*

text:
*From where do branches have that... coquetry and clear magic*
*Or that rose gathered... on his cheek and the jasmine*
Among them is one who says, he is Abu Ishaq Ibrahim bin al-Ash'ath]:
*If Mahmoud settles in a land, he... bursts in it a spring from the dew of his palm* (1)
*So it grows flowers resembling his gifts... some seen as silver (Wariq) and some seen as gold ('Ayn)* (2)
And he has regarding a beautiful dark-skinned boy:
*O you who spends his money... in the love of this surpassing gazelle* (3)
*What is silent gold considering it much... to make it go for the speaking gold* (4)
Among them is one who says about a beloved of his who stammers, he is Mahmoud bin Ismail bin Hamid Al-Damyati:
*A stammer (Tam-tamah) my love was completed (Temma) by it... and an obstacle that exposed me to sickness*
*And abundant hair my worry by it is abundant (Wafir)... and an eyebrow (Hajib) that blocked (Hajaba) sleep from me* (5)
And he has from verses describing wine:
*And I spent my night seeing the fire to which... the Magians prostrated, prostrating to me from the pitcher*

This - may Allah prolong the remaining of the High Presence - is what the mind dictated to the hand, in a time close at both ends, narrow between the two edges. If time allows, I will make up for what was missed (6) and append the deficient, Allah Almighty willing.
Completed on Tuesday the nineteenth of Dhu al-Qi'dah in the year 1091 in Edirne.
